analytic.title: An overview of the quantum cognition research programme

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: quantum cognition Running text word count: 28,324 Quantum Cognition

abstract.p: The quantum cognition research programme concerns the application of quantum probability theory (the rules for how to assign probabilities to events from quantum mechanics, without the physics) to cognitive modeling. We review quantum cognitive models in several areas of psychology, including conjunction/ disjunction fallacies in probabilistic judgment, conceptual combinations, similarity, order effects on judgments, causal inference, the disjunction effect in decision making, measurement and interference effects on judgments and decisions, memory, perception, and other judgment and decision-making applications. For each area, we first present the empirical findings that have motivated the application of quantum models, emphasizing any characteristics which are particularly puzzling or have resisted coherent theoretical explanations previously; we then discuss the quantum cognitive models, noting the key features of the models that help explain the empirical data; we finally cast a critical eye on the models and explore comparisons with non-quantum models.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Bayesian (classical) probability theory has been a hugely influential and dominant framework for understanding human decision making, reasoning, and inference, amongst other cognitive processes (e.g., see Griffiths et al., 2010;Oaksford & Chater, 1994;Tenenbaum et al., 2011). Equally, there have been persistent challenges to the applicability of baseline classical probability principles: in decision making, Tversky, Kahneman, Shafir and others have initiated a research programme into probabilistic fallacies, concerning empirical findings that violate classical probability theory, and so advocated heuristics biases, that are quick and easy to use, as the basis for human cognition, in at least some cases (this work has been recognized by two Nobel prizes, for Kahneman in 2002 and Thaler in 2017; e.g., Kahneman et al., 1982;Tversky & Kahneman, 1973, 1974, 1983Sloman, 1996). The importance of such findings is that they often challenge the most basic principles of Bayesian reasoning and, equally, that the conflict between Bayesian prescription and intuition is persistent -even when we are told the relevant Bayesian principle, it is sometimes difficult to overcome the (classically erroneous) intuition (cf. Gilboa, 2000). As another example, in memory, Reyna, Brainerd and others have reported results, challenging an expectation of consistency with basic classical probability constraints (such as the law of total probability, e.g., Brainerd et al., 2015;Reyna & Brainerd, 1995). There are several other examples, across different areas of psychology, even if in many cases classical probability theory remains the most successful framework for cognitive explanation.

Especially in decision making, models based on heuristics and biases have embodied a rich repertoire of novel theoretical concepts and processes (as examples see the references just above, as well as e.g. Gigerenzer & Goldstein, 1996;Hertwig et al., 2013;Hogarth & Einhorn, 1992;Nilsson et al., 2013). There is absolutely no doubt regarding the significance of these contributions. However, beyond classical (Bayesian) probability theory, a theoretical approach based on heuristics and biases need not be the default option when empirical findings indicate inconsistency with classical probability principles. Classical principles do not exhaust the formal probabilistic frameworks available to psychologists. Besides psychological efforts to extend baseline classical probability theory (e.g., with assumptions regarding sampling or the influence of pragmatics, Goodman et al., 2015;Griffiths et al., 2015;Sanborn et al., 2010;Shafer, 1976;Tversky & KÃ¶hler, 1994), it is also the case that there are alternative formal frameworks for probabilistic reasoning (Narens, 2015;Sorkin, 1994). So, even if classical probability theory were uniformly successful in cognition, there is a reasonable question of whether alternative approaches might sometimes offer an advantage.

The purpose of this review is to bring together theoretical work employing an alternative formal framework for probabilistic inference based on what we call quantum probability theory, the rules for how to assign probabilities to events from quantum mechanics without any of the physics (for introductions suited to psychologists, in decreasing complexity, see Busemeyer and Bruza, 2012, 2017; for introductions for philosophers and physicists see Hughes, 1989, andIsham, 1989). By reviewing and evaluating quantum cognitive models, we seek to answer questions such as: is there room for a probabilistic framework in cognition other than classical probability theory? Is there promise in the quantum set of probabilistic principles in cognition? Can quantum probability help us learn something new about cognition? Pothos and Busemeyer (2022) also reviewed some of these questions. Both Pothos and Busemeyer's review and the present one aim to cover the main concepts and offer an overview of relevant quantum models and empirical results, but the present review is intended to be more detailed and granular (both in terms of the models and empirical results that are covered).

The application of quantum probability theory to cognition (briefly, quantum cognition) has been ongoing for nearly fifteen years. The idea of applying quantum theory to psychology dates back to seminal articles by Aerts and Aerts (1995), Bordley (1998), Khrennikov (1999), and Atmanspacher et al. (2002). However, applying these ideas to empirical data became more widespread after a special issue in the Journal of Mathematical Psychology (2009, Vol 53, 5). Ashtiani and Azgomi (2015) survey the different types of quantum models applied to judgment and decision-making. Haven and Khrennikov (2013) describe applications beyond psychology to the more general field of social sciences. Other previous reviews of the quantum cognition research programme include Bruza, Wang, Busemeyer (2015) and .

Before embarking on a (lengthy) review, a key question is, in the words of a reviewer (Costello), "why would anyone expect human cognition to follow the rules of quantum probability?" After all, quantum mechanics was originally proposed as a theory of physics, for microscopic particles. There have been several physics theories, e.g., electromagnetism, classical mechanics, string theory etc. and in most cases there have been no attempts to extend applicability outside physics. So what is special about quantum mechanics, which has motivated some psychologists to think it might be relevant in cognition? There are three steps in answering this question.

First, as just noted, quantum mechanics involves a part which is a theory of probability -that is, a theory for how to assign probabilities to events (what we call quantum theory). Because manifestly much of cognition is about quantifying uncertainty, any theory of probability is, in principle, relevant in cognitive theory. This includes Bayesian theory, the variants and extensions which have been proposed (e.g., within cognition, the probability and noise model, from Costello & Watts, 2014), and any other probability theory -this includes quantum theory. A priori, given a theoretical objective of understanding human probabilistic inference, any theory of probability is relevant. Here, one might counterargue that quantifying uncertainty using Bayesian theory specifically matches the structure of the world. That is, the world conforms to a Boolean structure and so, when it comes to quantifying uncertainty in the world, Bayesian theory is uniquely appropriate. A problem with this counterargument is that the world also reflects contextuality and in such circumstances a contextual probability theory, such as quantum theory, might provide better descriptions (e.g., Aerts et al., 2015;Bruza et al., 2023;Cervantes & Dzhafarov, 2018; see also Aerts & Beltran, 2022;Aerts et al., 2024).

Second, the dominant probability approach in psychological theory, Bayesian theory, sometimes runs into difficulties, for example, the various fallacies from e.g. Kahneman, Tversky etc. This has motivated the search for alternative theory, to understand the emergence of such fallacies. Psychologists have often pursued explanations based on heuristics and biases and these have certainly allowed many powerful and important insights. Quantum theory is another candidate in principle, relevant for dealing with the apparent failures of baseline Bayesian theory. Note, this historical picture is analogous to that in physics and quantum mechanics. Abandoning classical physics principles was very difficult for the physics community (which can be conservative) and, initially, quantum mechanics had faced severe objections from the leading, at the time, physicists (e.g., Einstein, Poldosky, Rosen, 1964). It was only the close correspondence between theory and empirical data which gradually led to the acceptance of quantum mechanics in physics.

This leads us to the third point: regardless of whether one is convinced of the a priori relevance of quantum theory in cognition or not, in several cases quantum cognitive models have shown good correspondence with empirical data and demonstrated generative value, in terms of novel, surprising predictions. Again, this situation is analogous in physics: initially, quantum mechanics was adopted almost in an exploratory way, without a clear sense of why nature should be consistent with quantum mechanics -it has taken a long time for foundational arguments to emerge and even now this is an active research area (e.g., Hardy, 2002).

A related question here is whether the use of quantum probabilities entails, motivates, or requires a quantum brain, that is, an assumption that brain neurophysiology involves quantum mechanical processes (Hameroff, 2007). An argument might be along these lines: if there is quantum structure at the behavioral level, should this not be the result of quantum-mechanical processes in relation to the function of neurons? There are two parts to the answer here. First, throughout cognitive psychology, the theories which are invoked at the behavioral level involve principles which can describe regularities in behavior, without any claims about brain neurophysiology (cf. Griffiths et al., 2010;Marr, 1982). It is a peculiarity of our field that there are different, largely independent explanatory levels. Why should a description at the behavioral level require quantum mechanical processes at the neuronal level? This is like arguing that the use of Bayesian principles at the behavioral level must go hand in hand with Bayesian processes at the neuronal level. Note, such an argumentation, even if half-plausible for quantum or Bayesian behavioral models, makes no sense at all for many other behavioral level explanations (such as ones based on heuristics). Second, the use of quantum principles at the behavioral level is often described as quantum-like, exactly so as to emphasize that quantum mechanical processes at the neuronal level are not required for apparent quantum effects behaviorally. There have been several proposals for how classical models of neuronal function could lead to quantum-like effects and we will review these later (e.g., de Barros & Suppes, 2009;Khrennikov et al., 2018). However, be this as it may, it needs to be remembered that behavior is an emergent property of the function of millions or hundreds of millions of neurons and it is difficult to build bridges across such disparate explanatory levels.

Putting the above two points together, whether neuronal function involves quantum processes or not has no bearing on the plausibility of quantum-like models at the behavioral level. For example, the brain could be fully quantum, but behavior fully classical (that is, better described by classical principles). That is, even if the brain were quantum, quantum mechanical processes at the neuronal process might lead to classical structure in behavior -or vice versa. There are two related points. First, evidence for quantum mechanical processes at the neuronal level has been weak, despite proposals from influential scientists (Hameroff, 2007;Litt et al., 2006). Second, quantum mechanics has led to intense debate about reality, forcing us to rethink deeply ingrained intuitions about nature. For example, ontic uncertainty or spooky action at a distance have required radical revisions to our picture of reality. However, we shall see that the application of quantum theory in psychology eschews such problems: in their most part, effects which appear weird for physical systems have familiar interpretations in behavior (such as contextuality, interference, and constructive influences).

Finally, one might question the use of our label 'quantum', since this label is closely associated with a theory of physics and, as such, it might alienate some readers. Additionally, over the years, readers and reviewers have sometimes pointed out that our quantum-like models are essentially linear matrix algebra, e.g., for how to compute projections of vectors onto subspaces (as we shall see, this is a major building block of quantum-like cognitive models). We think there are two arguments for sticking with the label 'quantum'. The first argument is substantive. We are employing Born's rule for how to associate subspaces to probabilities. Born's rule also implies Gleason's theorem regarding the uniqueness of how to associate subspaces to probabilities. Related are Luder's rule for conditional probabilities and the interpretation of superpositions. Without going into detail, there is an extensive mathematical machinery linking subspaces and projections to probabilities. This machinery is rightfully considered part of quantum theory, at least the part that has to do with probabilistic inference. The second argument is practical. There is already more than 10 years' worth of research with quantum cognitive models and retaining the label 'quantum' helps bring this work together as a distinctive approach to cognitive modeling.

div.head: What is quantum probability theory?
div.p: We begin with an informal presentation of quantum probability theory focused on its key properties and differences compared to classical probability theory. To make the ideas less abstract, the presentation is based on the application of quantum theory on a famous decision fallacy, Tversky and Kahneman's (1983) conjunction fallacy. Briefly, conjunction fallacy is the finding that sometimes participants will consider a conjunction as more likely than either of the conjuncts individually. An example of a conjunction fallacy concerns a hypothetical person, Linda, described very much as a feminist and not at all like a bank teller. Participants considered more likely the conjunction that Linda is a feminist and bank teller, than the conjunct that Linda is a bank teller. Note, the conjunction fallacy has been extensively replicated and withstood the test of proposals for possible confounds or alternative explanations (notably conversational implicatures; e.g., Dulany & Hilton, 1991;Moro, 2009). Note, in the following presentation, we employ the terms "possibilities," "question answers," or "events" fairly interchangeably, with the term event typically being more common in technical discussions.

The conjunction fallacy is problematic for baseline classical probability theory because events are defined as subsets of a universal set containing all events. The intersection of feminism and bank teller sets is contained within the larger set of all bank tellers, and so the probability of the intersection must be smaller (or equal, see Figure 1). This constraint for classical probability becomes immediately apparent if we recast the situation with countable instances. For example, compare the number of days on which it rained and snowed in London in 2018 to the number of days when it just rained. Figure 1. A sample space of all possible Lindas consistent with the story. The subset for which both properties of bank teller and feminist are true can never be larger than the subset for the bank teller property alone. Figure 2. A caricature of Busemeyer et al.'s (2011) model for the conjunction fallacy, based on onedimensional subspaces. is the mental state and F, BT the feminist, bank teller properties.

Quantum probability theory works differently, and probabilities arise from the geometric relation between a vector representing the state and subspaces representing events. Table 1 summarizes the main terms. Additionally, in Table 2, we offer some relevant equations, which complement the presentation in main text (these equations become relevant later on in the review). Figure 2 shows a caricature of the quantum model for the conjunction fallacy (Franco, 2009;Busemeyer et al., 2011). Several simplifications are made, notably we employ a two-dimensional space, and each event is a one-dimensional subspace (i.e., a ray). The vertical black ray represents the event that Linda is a bank teller (BT) and the horizontal (orthogonal) black ray represents the event that she is not a bank teller. The red ray at 45 degrees represents the event that Linda is a feminist (F) and the orthogonal red ray represents the event that Linda is not a feminist. The belief or mental state of a participant prior to a judgment is represented by the unit length state vector denoted as in Figure 2. The location of the state with respect to the rays representing feminism and bank teller is determined by the Linda story; in this example, we can straightforwardly set the state to be similar (small angle) to feminism and dissimilar to bank teller. The probability that Linda is a bank teller is determined by projecting the state vector onto the black vertical ray for bank teller (green horizonal line) and then computing the squared length of the projection. The probability that Linda is a feminist and a bank teller is determined by first projecting the state vector onto the ray representing feminism (red line connecting the state vector to the feminist ray), and then projecting the previous result onto the ray representing bank teller (blue horizontal line), and finally computing the squared length of this last projection. All these elements are presented more carefully below. In Figure 2, the direct projection to the bank teller ray is shorter (lower probability) than the projection to the feminist ray first and then to the bank teller one -this illustrates how this simple caricature model can accommodate the conjunction fallacy.

Each elementary outcome to a question (e.g., 'Linda is a bank teller) is called a basis vector and all the basis vectors for a particular question form a basis set. Generally, in quantum probability theory, outcomes to questions can be more complex and correspond to subspaces of any dimensionality (not just rays as in the above example) and the state vector is embedded in an arbitrary dimensionality space, called a Hilbert space. The probability of a single possibility, e.g. feminism, equals | ! | " , where ! is a projection operator (matrix) corresponding to the feminism subspace, ! is the projection of the state, , onto the subspace, and | ! | " is the squared length of the projection. That is, probabilities depend on the match or overlap between the state vector and the subspaces for the relevant events.

This brings us to the first unique property of quantum probability theory (here and elsewhere) relative to classical probability theory. In Figure 2, the state | â© = | â© + |~â© is called a superposition. It is a linear combination of the bank teller basis vectors, i.e., | â©, |~â© (a, b are called amplitudes and are complex numbers whose squared moduli are probabilities). Note, we have employed the Dirac notation here, whereby | * â© indicates a column vector. | â© is called a ket and â¨ | is the complex conjugate of | â© (and so a row vector); it is called a bra. The inner product â¨ | â© is called a bracket. A superposition state indicates uncertainty of a kind unique to quantum theory: prior to a decision, the person neither agrees nor disagrees that Linda is a bank teller (it is as if the person has no (specific) opinion about this question) and the decision creates a possibility into being. For example, suppose a person in a state described as | â© = | â© + |~â© decides that Linda is actually a BT. Then, after the decision (measurement), his/ her state would change to become | â© = | â©. This process is called the collapse of the state vector. Such ontic uncertainty is fundamentally different from the more common epistemic uncertainty, which reflects lack of knowledge (Atmanspacher & Primas, 2003;Griffiths, 2013;Spekkens, 2007). In physics, the meaning of superpositions and the collapse of the state vector has led to extensive debate. For example, what does it mean for an electron to not have a position prior to measurement? In psychology, if anything, the situation is the converse, since it is often reasonable to assume that decisions change the mental state. Figure 2 illustrates a second key property of quantum probability theory, that questions/ possibilities in quantum theory can be incompatible. In the example, the bank teller and feminist questions are represented by different bases (black rays versus red rays), and this arrangement does not allow a simultaneous projection on basis vectors for both questions. If a person was told for a fact that one possibility is true (e.g., Linda is a feminist), then the state vector would collapse to the feminist ray, to reflect certainty about the feminist question. But this would introduce unavoidable uncertainty about the incompatible question of whether Linda is a bank teller (the new state vector | â© = | â© has nonzero projections to both the BT and ~BT rays). So, incompatibility implies uncertainty relations. Note, in physics, uncertainty relations mean, for example, that it is impossible to concurrently know the position and momentum of a particle and have led to extensive debate (e.g., Isham, 1989). In psychology, a basic way to approach uncertainty relations is that deciding that one event is true (e.g., that Linda is a feminist) creates a unique perspective or mindset for other, incompatible ones (e.g., that Linda is a bank teller).

For incompatible questions, a joint probability distribution does not exist (since we cannot concurrently resolve all questions) and so the classical notion of conjunction has to be modified. In quantum probability theory, it is possible to define sequential conjunctions, which are just like the classical analogues, but the conjuncts have to be evaluated sequentially (as in the Figure 2 example) and order matters. Let #$ and ! be the projectors for the possibilities that Linda is a bank teller and a feminist and note that #$ ! â ! #$ , i.e., the projectors are non-commuting. Then, the probability that Linda is a bank teller and then a feminist is (Figure 2) and the conditional probability that she is a bank teller given that she is a feminist is ( | ) = | #$ | ! â©| " , where | ! â© is a normalized state in the feminist subspace (this is Luder's law, Hughes, 1988). The interference term allows quantum theory to violate the law of total probability. To account for the conjunction fallacy, we require Î < â (~ & â ). Superposition states can be separable or entangled. Consider a participant deciding not just whether Linda is a Feminist (F), but also whether another person Jane is a political Activist (A) or not. Suppose that the judgment for Linda is independent from the judgment for Jane. Then we can write

That is, the state for Linda, Jane is given as the tensor product (the symbol â¨) for the state for each person individually. This state is called a separable state. Alternatively, suppose that Jane is a very good friend of Linda's, so that they are rather similar, and that we believe that Activism and Feminism go together. Then, an appropriate mental state might be

Such a state is called an entangled state and the corresponding property entanglement. In this case, we have a special entangled state called a Bell state, whereby a decision for Linda forces an outcome for Jane. Put differently, entanglement means that, for component questions A and B, we cannot write the state for the combined question as | â©â¨| â©, that is the combined state cannot be constructed by independently combining parts of the representation from | â© and then | â©. In physics, entanglement has led to intense debate, because the two systems can be physically separated yet arbitrary measurements on either of them can remain correlated -it can appear that a measurement on one system 'forces' an outcome on a space-separated system (this relates to the famous Einstein-Podolsky-Paradox, Hughes, 1989, or Isham, 1989. However, when dealing with mental concepts, entanglement is less philosophically challenging, because it can be attributed to some dependence between the systems, e.g., when considering the different component concepts of a composite one. Entanglement can allow supercorrelations. Consider two individuals, Linda (person A) and Jane (person B), and two binary questions about each person: questions A1, A2 for Linda, and questions B1, B2 for Jane. We can compute correlations (technically, expectation values E[Ai,Bj], labelling the binary outcomes for each question as Â±1) for all pairs composed of one question about Linda A and one question about Jane B. An ingenious result by Bell shows that any classical joint probability distribution formed by four binary random variables A1, A2, B1, B2 has to be consistent with a linear combination of the correlations called the CHSH inequality (this is a specific version of the Bell inequality, Clauser et al., 1969;Bell, 2004;Equation 3). . Bell showed that if A, B are described with a quantum entangled state, then the Bell bound can be exceeded (but another bound applies, the so-called Tsirelson bound). In this sense, entangled quantum systems can be supercorrelated. It is important to note that supercorrelations can also be a result of 'communication' between the two systems. What is unique about entanglement is that supercorrelations can even occur when no information is allowed to be transmitted between the two systems. In quantum physics, this can be established by having the two systems in an entangled state separated in two different localities. The non-locality requirement, however, is harder to enforce in psychological experiments.

So far, we have only described static/measurement assumptions. Quantum theory also applies to dynamic situations in which the state vector evolves across e.g. time, according to a unitary process derived from SchrÃ¶dinger's equation. A unitary process is analogous to a rotation of the state vector in a quantum space, so that with time the probabilities for the various possibilities change. This is analogous to dynamics in classical probability theory, in which the probability distribution over states evolves across time according to a Markov process derived from a Kolmogorov equation.

There are other, more complex technical details from quantum theory that can be applied to cognitive research. Instead of a state vector, a quantum system can also be represented by a density matrix = â ' ' | ' â©â¨ ' |, where ' 's reflect a mixture over states of the system (Comparo, 2013); in such cases, ( ) = ( % ), where the trace operation sums diagonal elements of a matrix. Instead of projection operators, probabilities can also be computed by positive-operator-valuedmeasures (POVMs), which are more general type of measurements. In particular, projectors imply repeatability (e.g., a second measurement produces the same result as the first), whereas POVM type measurements can be noisy and no longer subject to repeatability (Yearsley, 2017). Instead of unitary dynamics, one can alternatively employ what are called Lindblad dynamics, which incorporate open system environmental influences and can exhibit a characteristic pattern of oscillation followed by stabilization (Asano et al., 2011). Also, the process of measurement has led to intense debate. Rather than require that the state collapses to (identifies with) the question outcome, it is possible to specify the measurement interaction in more detail, as a dynamical process, using the 'instruments' formalism (Ozawa & Khrennikov, 2021;Tsuchiya et al., in press).

Overall, the key properties of quantum theory that lend themselves to psychological application are primarily superposition states and the collapse property, incompatibility, uncertainty relations and interference effects, entanglement and supercorrelations, though of course these properties are closely inter-dependent. Physicists have sought to reduce all of quantum theory into a single fundamental property (e.g., superposition; Harding 2001), but such considerations are beyond the present scope.

div.head: Research Review
div.p: The main objective of this review is to bring together and evaluate the more notable quantum cognitive models across psychology. This objective presents several challenges. First, quantum probability theory has been applied in very diverse cognitive areas. We identified notable applications in conjunction/ disjunction fallacies in probabilistic judgment, conceptual combinations, similarity, order effects on judgments, causal inference, the disjunction effect in decision making, measurement and interference effects on judgments and decisions, memory, perception, and other judgment and decision-making applications; a summary is provided in Table 3. Even though all applications of quantum theory share some common elements, different empirical domains come with their own unique research questions and interests. Therefore, we organize quantum cognitive models according to empirical domain and note that coverage and evaluation in certain areas will be a lot more extensive than in others, an inevitable consequence of differences in the interests of the research community. For each empirical domain, we will consider the relevant findings, describe how the quantum models account for the findings, and present a critical evaluation with respect to non-quantum models. Regarding the latter, our purpose is not to provide a comprehensive review of the corresponding debates (some of which are so extensive as to warrant independent, substantive reviews), but rather to selectively focus on an evaluation of quantum models.

The second challenge is that even within an empirical domain, in some cases theoretical work can extend over several different empirical findings and paradigms. This precludes an organization of the review based on e.g. common characteristics or features between empirical tools, as would be the case in more standard empirically driven reviews. Instead, systematization has to be achieved from the way different theoretical proposals are covered and evaluated. A related challenge is that rigorous inclusion, exclusion criteria cannot be specified. Instead, we have been guided by a sense of which quantum cognitive models have been more notable, based on technical rigor, empirical applicability, and recognition in the relevant research communities. Clearly, in part, these are subjective judgments.

Overall, the objective in the present review is not to consider every single application of quantum probability theory in psychology. Rather, it is to showcase the way quantum models have contributed new theoretical and technical tools in different areas of psychology and evaluate these contributions in relation to competing non-quantum theories. Table 3. An overview of the empirical domains considered, with a brief summary of the key findings in each domain and a list of corresponding quantum papers.

div.head: Conjunction/ disjunction fallacies in probability judgment
div.p: Conjunction fallacy and disjunction fallacy are perhaps the strongest and best-studied evidence that human probability judgments do not follow the Kolmogorov axioms. In the following, we will review approaches using quantum probability theory to account for this fallacy and some remaining controversy and open questions in using quantum probability models for explaining related findings.

Empirical research. There are a range of related results examining probability judgment errors, including conjunction fallacies (Tversky & Kahneman, 1983;Moro, 2009), disjunction fallacies (Bar-Hillel & Neter, 1993;Carlson & Yates, 1989;Fisk, 2002), unpacking effects (Rottenstreich & Tversky, 1997;Sloman, Rottenstreich, Wisniewski, Hadjichristidis, & Fox, 2004), and more complex conjunctions (e.g., Winman, Nilsson, Juslin, & Hansson, 2010). Using the terminology from Tversky and Kahneman's (1983) paradigmatic Linda example, where BT=bank teller, F=feminist, the conjunction fallacy is ( â§ ) > ( ). The disjunction fallacy is ( â¨ ) < ( ) (note, this is not to be confused with the disjunction effect, see later, . Conjunction effects often arise when combining an unlikely conjunct with a likely one and/or when the conjuncts have a strong causal association (e.g., Moro, 2009). Unpacking effects are violations of the law of total probability e.g. instances of subadditivity, whereby ( ) < ( â§ ) + ( â§~). More recently, Huang et al. (2024a) and Huang et al. (2024b) studied a large number of probability judgments, relating to the last US presidential election, in 2020. They asked their participants to respond to 78 probability judgments each, corresponding to all possible probability expressions involving three events: Biden would win in State A; Biden would win in State B; Biden would win in State C. Two triplets of states were used the tacit negations of the basic events were that Trump would win in the corresponding states. They replicated all existing fallacies, such as conjunction and disjunction fallacies. Additionally, they reported frequent double conjunction and disjunction fallacies and a fairly novel effect of violation of binary complementarity. In its simplest form, binary complementarity is the constraint that Prob(A)+Prob(~A)=1. Huang et al. (2024b) observed systematic overestimations in the basic binary complementarity expression, as well as other ones. Gronchi and Strambini (2017) presented a variant of the Linda problem to test the Wignerd'Espagnat inequality (Equation 4, d 'Espagnat, 1979). The Wigner-d'Espagnat inequality is a version of Bell's inequality (Bell, 2004) better suited to Linda-style paradigms (a Venn diagram illustrates how trivial this is from a classical perspective when all possibilities are represented in the same sample space). Bell notably stated, "trivial as it is, the inequality is not respected by quantum mechanical probabilities'' (Bell, 1981, p. 52). Gronchi and Strambini (2017) reported two experiments concerning the probability of picking different objects from an urn or of male vs. female students more likely to be playing soccer. In the first experiment the results indicated violations of the Wigner-d'Espagnat inequality. In a second experiment, when participants directly estimated unpacked probabilities (that is, the two probability terms in the Wigner-d'Espagnat inequality), Wigner-d'Espagnat violations disappeared, thus indicating that a subadditivity pattern (Equation 4) possibly accounts for Wignerd'Espagnat violations.

Quantum cognitive models. Busemeyer et al. (2011) employed a quantum probability model in which a conjunction fallacy emerges from Equation (2). Note, this decomposition implies that the conjunctive statement F&BT is evaluated in terms of a projection first to the F subspace and then to the BT one, an assumption justified through appeal to heuristics prioritizing the processing of more likely information (Gigerenzer & Todd, 1996). Concretely, a conjunction fallacy can be obtained if the following two conditions are fulfilled. First, | #$~! | â©| " has to be small, which is reasonable because the story makes ~F unlikely. Second, the interference term has to be negative, which is the case if the features matching "feminist bank teller" are negatively correlated with the features matching "not feminist bank teller". In the Busemeyer et al. (2011) account of conjunction/ disjunction errors the order used to evaluate the questions is critical. Miyadera and Phillips (2012) proposed an extension of this theory that employed positive operator valued measurements and which can produce conjunction errors without necessarily requiring order effects. Huang et al. (2023), Huang (2023), and Huang et al. (2024a) also provided an extension to the Busemeyer et al. (2011) model, by assuming a response process based on a sequential sampling mechanism, with drifts corresponding to quantum probabilities and a bias. Aerts (2009) also has a quantum model for conjunction and disjunction fallacies. However, this model will be discussed later in the section on conceptual combinations.

Gronchi and Strambini (2017) produced two quantum models to account for violations of Wigner-d'Espagnat. The first model is based on applying two non-commutative projections, representing incompatible events, on a quantum state in the same space and so this approach is analogous to that of Pothos and Bysemeyer (2009). The second model assumes that the two questions for each logical operation in the Wigner-d'Espagnat equation are represented by two commutative projections, representing compatible events, acting on different parts of a joint quantum state. In this construction there will be a violation of Wigner-d'Espagnat inequality only when the joint quantum state has inseparable subparts, namely when the state is entangled. The two models were shown to provide equivalent empirical coverage for violations of Wigner-d'Espagnat inequality.

Critical evaluation and controversy. One important contribution of quantum models of probability judgments is that they provide a new measure of probability that is not restricted by Kolmogorov axioms and set theory. The Venn diagram picture of events as subsets of a sample space makes it impossible to imagine a conjunction as more likely than a marginal (Figure 1). Yet the geometric picture of events as subspaces of a vector space in quantum theory allows us to do so and shows how earlier projections can change our perspective for later ones and so result in a sequential conjunction being more probable than a corresponding marginal ( Figure 2). Moreover, Pothos et al. (2017) showed that quantum theory is consistent with the Dutch Book criterion for rational behavior (de Finetti et al., 1993) and that a conjunction fallacy can be rational when the questions are contextual (the presence of one question alters the meaning of the other) or disturbing. More generally, Busemeyer et al.'s (2011) work has encompassed a range of fallacies related to the conjunction fallacy, notably the disjunction fallacy and unpacking effects.

Most decision results which have been considered fallacies can be reconciled with (baseline) classical probability theory through appropriate conditionalization. For example, regarding the conjunction fallacy, one could write

, where fm1, fm2 can correspond to different measurement contexts (e.g., frame of minds; Dzhafarov & Kon, in press). Indeed, from a psychological perspective, an explanation based on measurement contexts might appear analogous to the quantum one. However, one hardly ever encounters such models, because an arbitrary, post hoc conditionalization carries low explanatory power. We will therefore discount such possibilities in subsequent discussion. Busemeyer et al. (2011) explained the conjunction fallacy by event incompatibility. Accordingly, if this explanation is correct, manipulations that encourage processing of the conjuncts in a concurrent (compatible) way should reduce conjunction fallacies. Empirical findings show that training on the algebra of sets (Agnoli & Krantz, 1989; see also Yamagishi, 2003, andWolfe &Reyna, 2010) and feedback training on the classical probability rule (Nilsson, 2008) can reduce conjunction fallacies, which is consistent with this hypothesis as this kind of training should encourage compatibility. Familiarity is also thought to induce transitions from incompatible to compatible representations; for example, Nilsson et al. (2013) showed that conjunction fallacy is reduced when familiarity increases.

The quantum explanation of the conjunction fallacy is predicated on evaluating the more likely conjunct first, assuming the two predicates are incompatible. This implies that judgments on the two predicates must also result in order effects. There is some evidence that manipulating processing order produces order effects with conjunctions (Stolarz-Fantino et al., 2003, Experiment 2;Gavanski & Roskos-Ewoldsen, 1991). A more direct demonstration was provided by Yearsley and Trueblood (2018), who reported the co-occurrence of conjunction fallacies and order effects (we provide some more detail in the section on "Order effects on judgments"). However, Boyer-Kassem et al. (2016) examined order effects for seven different pairs of questions that had produced conjunction fallacies in past research, but reported order effects in only two cases, no order effects in two other cases, and ambiguous results in the remaining three cases. This apparent null result is undermined by their use of the Bonferroni correction for family-wise error, which has been criticized as too conservative (Nakagawa, 2004;Perneger, 1998), and the lack of an observation of concurrent conjunction fallacies (which contrasts with Yearsley & Trueblood, 2018). It is possible that their sample was less prone to order effects and conjunction fallacies (their participants were students in economics, management, or medicine).

Several other models for conjunction and disjunction fallacies have been proposed. Tversky and Kahneman (1983;Shafir et al., 1990) proposed a representativeness heuristic, so that probability judgments are essentially similarity processes. Thus, probabilistic inference is relegated to a more generic cognitive process. However, the similarity mechanism in representativeness is underspecified. Note that probability in the quantum model is sometimes equivalent to overlap between two vectors in some space (the mental state vector and a vector along the way representing a particular question, e.g., whether Linda is a feminist). Such overlap in psychological space has been argued to correspond to similarity computations, in some proposals (Sloman, 1993). So, stretching a little bit the corresponding ideas, we could consider the quantum model for the conjunction fallacy as a way to formalize the representativeness heuristic.

Another class of models that purport to explain such fallacies is averaging models (Abelson, Leddo, & Gross, 1987;Fantino, Kulik, & Stolarz-Fantino, 1997;Nilsson, 2008;Nilsson et al., 2009). The basic idea of averaging models is very intuitive: probability of conjunctions reflects some weighted average of the probabilities of the individual conjuncts. However, there are some well-documented problems with such models. Notably, they cannot distinguish (without additional assumptions) between situations when the two conjuncts are strongly causally related vs. not. Indeed, Tversky and Kahneman (1983) had discussed the conjunction fallacy in cases such as "Mr. F has had one or more heart attacks and Mr. F is older than 55" vs. the lack of a fallacy when participants consider "Mr. F has had one or more heart attacks and Mr. G is older than 55." This difference cannot be easily explained with averaging models. Averaging models also have difficulty distinguishing between conjunctions and disjunctions (this is accomplished through the use of different weights). proposed an inductive confirmation account of conjunction fallacies; however, this proposal does not attempt to account for disjunction effects. According to inductive confirmation, probability estimates for hypotheses given evidence are driven by the difference (â| ) â (â), where h is a hypothesis and e is evidence . This account dissociates the degree of conjunction fallacy from the probability of the more likely conjunct. Tentori et al.'s (2013) evidence for this proposal was based on a task that involved a hypothetical woman who is Russian (R), lives in New York (NY), and in addition is an interpreter (I). Their main finding was ( â§ | ) > ( | ), even though the I possibility is less likely than the ~I one , express this as (~| â§ ) > ( | â§ )). Thus, in this scenario and variants the conjunction fallacy arises from a less likely conjunct (being an I). The quantum conjunction fallacy model can account for Tentori et al.'s (2013) results . Additionally, argued that order effects in the consideration of the conjuncts (Stolarz-Fantino et al., 2003, Experiment 2;Gavanski & Roskos-Ewoldsen, 1991) support the quantum account, but not the inductive confirmation one.

Another potential advantage of the quantum probability model over the inductive confirmation model is that it is capable of predicting quantitative probability judgments measured on rating scales, while the inductive confirmation theory only forecasts when a conjunction fallacy would occur without predicting the fallacy's magnitude. However, there have been some limited reports of a finding, double conjunction fallacies (Crupi et al., 2018), which is problematic for the quantum model, but can be explained by the inductive confirmation account. Huang et al. (2024a) reported more extensive evidence for double conjunction fallacies, indicating that the original Busemeyer et al. (2011) model needs some revision.

In the probability theory plus noise account, probability judgments are based on classical probability theory, but subject to error (Costello & Watts, 2014;. To account for conjunction fallacies, the amount of noise is assumed to be greater for conjunctions as compared to single conjuncts, otherwise the model cannot predict systematic conjunction errors. Noise arises because probability estimates are based either on enumerating relevant memory instances or a mental simulation of such instances. Costello, Watts, and Fisher (2018) derived several probabilistic expressions which diverge depending on whether one adopts quantum rules or probability plus noise rules. Their results appear to uniformly support their model, not quantum theory. Their criticism is mainly focused on the assumption by the quantum model that incompatible events are necessary to account for the conjunction fallacy. Note, quantum theorists have been incorporating noise in their work too (e.g., Yearsley and Pothos, 2016). However, noise has not been explored for the conjunction fallacy, because in quantum theory noise emerges as a small probability that the internal computation may produce A, but one may mistakenly pronounce ~A. Therefore, in quantum models the role of noise should be more relevant in situations of multiple decisions.

The probability plus noise model has many strengths, including its Bayesian origins and strong intuition. But there are some concerns as well. For example, there is no evidence that cognitive processes give rise to sampling independence for estimating related probabilities (e.g., marginals and a conjunction), but without sampling independence the noise model cannot predict the conjunction fallacy. Additionally, some further clarity is needed in how the essential idea applies to different probability terms (e.g., conditional probabilities; Costello & Watts, 2016 and the role of error in probabilities is implausible for completely impossible or certain events. Finally, Costello and Watts's (2014) prediction for a conjunction fallacy relies on Prob(Aâ§B) being close to Prob(A), but reported conjunction fallacy results at odds with this requirement. Notwithstanding these points, the probability plus noise model has been the focus of current research and it is possible that in future iterations some of these issues will be addressed.

Do Costello et al.'s (2018) results challenge the quantum model? consider familiarity to equate with compatibility and there is evidence that this is the case (e.g., Yearsley & Trueblood, 2018). However, we think that even familiar questions might be incompatible, if they induce different perspectives to each other, as seems apparent for order effects regarding the Clinton, Gore honesty questions . However, there are also aspects captured by the probability plus noise model that are not captured by a quantum probability model. For example, Costello et al. 's (2018) work shows violation in conditional probability judgments which are not explained by the quantum probability model. This suggests that fallacies in probability judgment are not limited to conjunction and disjunction fallacies, and a more general quantum model is needed to cover all the results from .

A more recent related model which builds on some ideas from the probability plus noise model is the Bayesian sampler model (Zhu et al., 2020). In the Bayesian sampler, conjunction and disjunction fallacies are explained by observers running fewer mental samples of conjunctions compared with the isolated conjunct. The Bayesian sampler model is claimed to account for more probability judgment fallacies than the probability plus noise model. Overall, this is a compelling model. We just note that, just like for the probability plus noise model, the Bayesian sampler explains the conjunction and disjunction fallacy by assuming sampling independence for composite vs. singleton judgments. A detailed comparison between Zhu et al.'s (2020) model and Huang et al.'s (2024a) quantum model, adjusting for complexity, favored the quantum model.

To summarize the discussion so far, we think there some reasonable concerns for the probability plus noise model and the Bayesian sampler. Equally, work to support these models has also highlighted shortcomings with the original quantum model for the conjunction fallacy (from Busemeyer et al., 2011).

Boyer-Kassem et al. 2016argued that a two-dimensional quantum model (like that shown in Figure 2) for the conjunction fallacy entails consistency with the grand reciprocity equalities (which they derived). They reported empirical violations of grand reciprocity, which they claimed go against the quantum model. However, the grand reciprocity property requires the assumption that each event is represented by a pure quantum state and rays in complex Hilbert Space (as in Figure 2). On the contrary, Busemeyer et al.'s (2011) model is not restricted in this way; in their example events were represented as multi-dimensional subspaces, because it is unlikely that complex psychological concepts (like feminism) would have one-dimensional (single feature) representations . Using multi-dimensional subspaces means that the law of reciprocity need not be obeyed (using POVMs can achieve a similar effect). Gronchi and Strambini's (2017) work brings into focus a key issue, that violations of the Wignerd'Espagnat inequality can arise either because of incompatibility in the same space or compatible representations in separate spaces with an entangled state. Both incompatibility and entanglement can preclude a joint probability distribution, but in the former case because of uncertainty relations and in the latter because of the impossibility to describe the corresponding entities independently of each other. However, researchers may require a commitment to incompatibility or compatibility in any situation. In Gronchi and Strambini's (2017) experiments, questions regarding the color or shape of objects are likely to be treated as compatible (because perceptual physical properties like this are unlikely to have a contextual influence on each other), but gender and likelihood of playing different sports incompatible (if different genders change our perspective for likely sports).

div.head: Conceptual combinations
div.p: Empirical research. There are a range of related results examining membership judgments for conceptual combinations, including membership for conjunctions, disjunctions, and negations of concepts. There has been a lot of attention concerning overextension and underextension effects. The former concern situations like a goldfish. A goldfish is a better member of the conjunction of the concepts pet and fish (i.e., pet-fish), than either of concepts individually (Hampton, 1988a;Osherson & Smith, 1981;Storms et al., 1999). Underextension occurs when observers judge strongly an item to belong to some category A and, separately, to another category B, but only weakly to the disjunction of the two categories (A or B). For example, this occurs for a refrigerator, relative to the categories of furniture and home furnishings (Hampton, 1988b). Aerts, Sozzo, and Veloz (2018) also studied negations with conceptual conjunctions, e.g., fruits and vegetables, fruits and not vegetables, not fruits and vegetables, and not fruits and not vegetables. In addition to overextension effects, they also found violations of total probability. For example, the rating for chili pepper being a spice was less than the sum of the ratings for spice and herb plus spice and not herb.

A different line of research examined issues concerning whether or not conceptual combinations are compositional as opposed to non-compositional. Intuitively, for a compositional conceptual combination, each constituent concept maintains its meaning independently of the other constituent concepts. More formally, suppose we have four conceptual questions A1, A2, B1, B2 which can be true or false (e.g., it can fly/ it cannot fly). These questions can be combined into pairs forming conceptual combinations (e.g., is A1 true and is B1 false). Each of these conceptual questions corresponds to a random variable and the resulting conceptual combinations to joint probabilities. The resulting conceptual combinations are compositional, if the individual random variables are consistent with a joint probability distribution for all four variables. The Bell inequality (Equation 3) provides a corresponding test. A failure of compositionality indicates that some of the random variables/ conceptual questions are contextual, so that their meaning changes depending on which other questions are asked.

Using novel, ambiguous conceptual combinations, , designed an experiment to test for compositionality. Each conceptual combination involved two words, chosen so that the meaning of each word individually would be ambiguous. For example, in 'spring plant', the meaning of plant could be either a living organism of a certain kind or machinery used in industrial settings. Each participant received one of four primes (a single word), corresponding to the 2 x 2 meaning possibilities, and subsequently was asked to interpret the ambiguous concept and rate the sense of each component word that was employed. The authors then compiled conditional probabilities for the interpretation of each concept combination, given particular primes, which could be employed to test for violations of a variant of the Bell inequality. Violations of Bell were observed, indicating non-compositionality, that is, the meaning of the pair of words could not be determined on the basis of the meaning of each word individually, independently of its context.

Non-compositionality in concept combinations was also found using a similar design, but different conceptual combinations. Aerts et al. (2018) asked participants to pick a pair of wind directions (e.g., North and Southwest vs. South and Northeast), that they considered 'good examples of two different wind directions'. Across several trials, participants were presented with choice sets including different combinations of pairs of wind directions. By analogy with entanglement experiments in physics, a first system would involve two directions A, A' and a second system two different wind directions B, B', so that overall we would have four combinations of wind directions (AB, AB' etc.), with each combination specifying a trial (since e.g. each of A, B are binary questions, there are four possibilities for the combined question A, B and participants would choose one). The design was fully within participants. The main empirical finding was that averaged participant responses violated the CHSH inequality, so that a complete joint probability distribution for the four relevant events is impossible.

Non-compositionality in concept associations was further explored by Cervantes and Dzhafarov (2018). Participants were presented with one A question and one B question, such that A1: Gerda or Troll, A2: Snow Queen or Old Finn woman, B1: Beautiful or Unattractive, B2: Kind or Evil. Participant responses were used to compute expectations e.g. [ 1, 1], by coding question answers with Â±1. Cervantes and Dzhafarov (2018) reported violations of the CHSH, hence demonstrating noncompositionality in concept associations of this kind.

A challenging issue in conceptual reasoning concerns borderline vagueness, the idea that for many concepts there are no clearly defined boundaries and there are borderline cases for which it is unclear whether the predicate applies. The Sorites paradox exemplifies such problems. Start by stating that if X is a heap of sand, then removing one grain will surely result in still having a heap. However, the repeated application of this rule results in the paradox that the last grain left must still count as a heap. Alxatib and Pelletier (2011) empirically examined borderline combinations (is 'X is tall and not tall') and found that borderline contradictions were commonly accepted.

Quantum cognitive models. Aerts and colleagues (2009; see also Aerts & Gabora, 2005a, 2005bAerts, Gabora, Sozzo, 2014;Aerts, Sozzo, & Veloz, 2015) developed a quantum theory for conceptual combination, called the "state-context-property" theory, which is one of the earliest quantum models in psychology. This model can also be applied to probability judgment errors such as conjunction and disjunction fallacies (Aerts, 2009). The state-context-property theory uses an expanded Hilbert space called a Fock space, which can be thought of as a combination of different Hilbert spaces. For a conceptual combination between concepts A, B, Aerts (2009) proposed a combination of two Hilbert spaces: one used a tensor product between the (quantum) representations for concepts A, B; the other used a superposition of concepts A, B (Equation 5). Note, this combination rule is applied to both conjunctions and disjunctions, but with different parameters allowed for each type of combination. The tensor product space component was designed to satisfy classical conceptual combination, and the superposition component was designed to produce non-classical judgments. Interference effects arise from the superposition part (see Equation 2), which allow the modelling of overextensions and underextensions. This model purports to formalize the idea of two separate routes to concept combination, a classical one and a quantum one. Aerts et al. (2018) also developed a quantum model with an entangled initial state and four tensor product measurements to account for their violations of the CHSH inequality for their experiment on wind directions. Aerts et al. (2018) represented the questions about wind directions with tensor products of the form ( â¢ ) â ( â¢ ), where a, b are direction vectors and = : + ; + < , the Pauli spin matrices. In order to describe correlations between binary measurements in two subsystems (i.e., the responses for each of two wind directions, for each subsystem), one needs to identify four direction vectors a, b, a', b' and an entangled state. The authors claim that there is no guarantee of a suitable quantum representation of this kind. But, they identified an entangled mental state and wind directions which described the observed correlations.
In the work of Cervantes and Dzhafarov (2018) a specific quantum model was not provided, rather the Bell violation was taken as indication of quantum-like contextuality.

Blutner et al. 2013developed a quantum model where probabilities corresponded to activation patterns in a Hopfield network with a single input unit representing the statement of interest (e.g., "John is tall") and two output units representing truth, falsity. The statement could be characterized in one of three ways, definite truth, definite falsity, and truth and falsity at the same time -this last pattern expresses a 'glut' and is a feature of borderline vagueness. Probabilities were assigned to each of these three possibilities using the Boltzmann distribution. The main assumption was that the projectors for truth and falsity were not orthogonal, allowing emergence of interference terms, which affected the normalization factors for the Boltzmann distribution probabilities.

Critical evaluation and controversy. Aerts (2009) reported exact reproductions of overextension and underextension effects in conceptual combination, covering both conjunctive and disjunctive categories (mostly using Hampton's, 1988aHampton's, , 1988b. However, this was achieved by using a number of model parameters that equaled or exceeded the data degrees of freedom. Nevertheless, standard conceptual combination approaches have difficulty with such effects. For example, Hampton (2011) discussed fuzzy logic averaging approaches to overextensions, underextensions, and negations to conclude that they fail to appropriately capture interactions between concepts. Hampton (2011) argued that a prototype model is more promising, but his approach involves various heuristic assumptions; so a formalized approach (such as Aerts's, 2009) may provide a more coherent explanation across the range of relevant findings. identified some conceptual combinations for which there was evidence of non-compositionality. These results impact on approaches to conceptual combination requiring compositionality (e.g., Fodor's, 1994), but less so for proposals based on emergent properties (Hampton, 1997) for which a compositional constraint is less central. Non-compositionality and weaker forms of compositionality are now well established in the conceptual combination literature (Swinney et al., 2007). The main contribution of is providing a formal framework for assessing compositionality/ contextuality. One can envisage a model with an entangled state , but a demonstration of contextuality does not necessitate a quantum model.

The interpretation of violations of Bell/ CHSH inequalities from Aerts et al. (2018) and involves some controversy. Several different concepts are relevant here and their precise relation can be a little confused, but the essential idea can be described with the notion of signaling. Suppose you ask questions A1, A2 for system A and questions B1, B2 for system B. No-signaling occurs when the marginal probability of question A1 in the context of B1 is the same as the marginal probability of A1 in the context of B2. Signaling occurs when there is interaction between the systems A, B, e.g., disturbance and/or communication (exactly what is meant by disturbance and communication can vary). In physics, it has been possible to observe violations of Bell/ CHSH inequalities, in the absence of signaling (in landmark demonstrations widely interpreted as indicating quantum structure in the microscopic world, e.g., Aspect, 1982). In psychology, Dzhafarov, Zhang, and Kujala (2016) argued that violations of the Bell inequality, such as those reported by Aerts et al. (2018) and , tend to go hand in hand with signaling, indicating interaction between the two 'systems' and precluding a conclusion of contextuality/ quantum-like structure. Dzhafarov and Kujala (2013) developed a generalized version of the CHSH test that is argued to test contextuality beyond what can be expected by signaling (Equation 6). Cervantes and Dzhafarov (2018) reported a violation this generalized CHSH inequality, and so argued that their finding constituted the first evidence of contextuality in human judgments. There is some controversy regarding the extent to which signaling can be corrected for (Atmanspacher & Filk, 2019) or how important it is to correct for it, e.g., when the objective is to establish non-compositionality (Waddup et al., 2021).

Blutner at al. 2013showed that Alxatib and Pelletier's (2011) experimental data could be fit by their quantum model, but not a closely matched classical one (for which probability assignment was identical to the quantum one, with the exception of the normalization factor for which interference terms arose in the quantum case). That is, the main empirical finding could be seen as arising from a violation of the law of total probability, so that interference effects from quantum probabilities provided an appropriate modeling instrument.

div.head: Similarity
div.p: Similarity is a core cognitive process that is assumed to facilitate other processes such as categorization and learning. Geometric and feature-based approaches are the two most prominent classes of models used to describe similarity.

Empirical research. Geometric models assume that objects or concepts are represented as points in a multidimensional, metric space, where the similarity between any two objects is a function of the distance between the points that represent those objects (e.g., Shepard, 1987;Kruskal & Wish, 1978;Nosofsky, 1984). Therefore, the more similar two stimuli are, the closer their points will be positioned in the multidimensional space, and the less similar two stimuli are, the further their points will be positioned in the space. Since the geometric models assume similarity is a function of distance in a metric space, they are required to obey the metric axioms: minimality, symmetry, and the triangle inequality. In terms of similarity, minimality states that the similarity between a stimulus and itself is maximal, symmetry states the similarity of stimulus A to stimulus B is equal to the similarity of stimulus B to stimulus A, and the triangle inequality states that the dissimilarity between stimulus A and stimulus C plus the dissimilarity between stimulus C and stimulus B must be equal to or greater than the dissimilarity between stimulus A and stimulus B. The triangle inequality is more difficult to assess in terms of similarity judgments, so further explanation for this point is included in the following paragraph. Tversky (1977) demonstrated violations of all three axioms, which suggests the distancebased similarity function may be a fundamentally flawed approach to similarity.

To demonstrate violations of symmetry, Tversky (1977) reported that people systematically judged the similarity of, for example, (North) Korea to (Mainland) China to be greater than the similarity of China to Korea (several other pairs of stimuli were employed; China and Korea are generally employed as the most paradigmatic example). Violations of symmetry have been demonstrated on multiple occasions (e.g., Aguilar & Medin, 1999). For violations of the triangle inequality, Tversky (1977) used William James's example, whereby Similarity (Russia, Jamaica) is low, but Similarity (Russia, Cuba) is high (because of political affiliation) and Similarity(Cuba, Jamaica) is also high (because of geographical proximity), so that Dissimilarity(Russia, Jamaica) > Dissimilarity(Russia, Cuba) + Dissimilarity (Cuba, Jamaica). However, despite the strong intuition for the triangle inequality, Tversky's (1977) example concerns violations of the triangle inequality on distances, not similarities. That is, the triangle inequality constraint (from an assumed metric representation) is that Distance (Russia, Jamaica) < Distance(Russia, Cuba) + Distance(Cuba, Jamaica). It is not straightforward to translate an inequality on distance to one on similarities. Tversky was clearly aware of this issue (in later work he considered violations of the related corner inequality, Tversky & Gati, 1982), but it seems to have been ignored in some of the subsequent literature (for an exception see Nosofsky, 1984). Considering options for how to convert the triangle inequality on distances to similarities, Yearsley et al. 2017derived a so-called multiplicative triangle inequality (based on Shepard's, 1987, function for relating distances to similarities). In addition to the violations of the metric axioms, Tversky (1977) also reported that similarity is susceptible to contextual influences from non-targeted alternatives in the choice set, which was coined the diagnosticity effect. For example, Tversky (1977) reported that out of Hungary, Sweden, Poland, the country chosen as most similar to Austria is Sweden, but out of Hungary, Sweden, Norway, the country chosen as most similar to Austria is Hungary.

In reaction to these findings, Tversky (1977) proposed the contrast model of similarity, which gave rise to the broader class of featural models. Featural models assume that stimuli are decomposed into explicit features and similarity between two stimuli is a function of their number of shared features minus the number of distinctive ones. Although the contrast model can account for violations of the metric axioms, the concept of salience is ill-defined and has proven difficult to apply to other sets of stimuli.

Finally, researchers have recognized that matching parts between object representations can have a greater influence on similarity judgments, than mismatching parts (e.g., Gentner, 1983;Goldstone, 1994). To account for this finding, alignment models have been developed to incorporate the structure of stimuli into similarity judgments.

Quantum cognitive models. A prior motivation for applying quantum theory in similarity is that it involves geometric representations and geometric representations have consistently featured prominently in similarity models (Kruskal & Wish, 1978;Nosofsky, 1984;Shepard, 1987). Whereas traditional geometric models use a point-wise representation (each object corresponds to a single point), in quantum theory representations can be (potentially multidimensional) subspaces. Differences in subspace dimensionality are a natural way to capture differences in knowledge between concepts in a quantum approach. Additionally, quantum probabilities embody order effects and are contextual, which are baseline requirements for violations of symmetry and the diagnosticity effect. developed a model of similarity judgments as quantum conjunctive probabilities. The quantum geometric model of similarity judgments can generate violations of symmetry in one of two ways. Either by using a biased initial state, where the projection of the initial state vector onto one subspace is greater (in length) than the projection of the initial state vector onto the other subspace, or by using noncommutative projectors, such that the order of projection alters the similarity judgment. To produce violations of symmetry of conceptual stimuli (e.g., China and Korea), assumed that the dimensionality of the subspace representing China was greater than that of the subspace representing Korea and an initially neutral state at the beginning of each similarity judgment. The dimensionality of a subspace was meant to represent different ideas/knowledge of the stimulus the subspace represents. Therefore, in parallel with Tversky's notion of relative salience determining the direction of asymmetry, extent of knowledge determines the direction of asymmetry in the quantum model. The quantum model immediately reproduces the observed asymmetry, i.e., the similarity of Korea to China was greater than the similarity of China to Korea, as long as the dimensionality of the subspace representing China is greater than the one for Korea.

To produce an asymmetry between the similarities of perceptual stimuli (e.g., colors), Epping et al. 2023offered two adaptations to prior work with quantum theory and similarity. First, all subspaces were assumed to have the same dimensionality, because there should be no differences in extent of knowledge across colors. Second, instead of assuming an unbiased, initial state, allowed for a biased initial state, whose particular placement could depend on any of three possible mechanisms. The first mechanism is a primacy vs recency one, biasing the state either towards the first or second color in the similarity judgment. The second one is a serial dependence mechanism, such that the final state of the previous similarity judgment influences the position of the subsequent initial state. Finally, the third mechanism is a salience mechanism, which biases the initial state toward the color with greater 'attention-grabbing' properties. Based on a model fitting exercise, concluded that there was only evidence in support of the primacy versus recency mechanism. Therefore, this runs contrary to Tversky's account that differences in perceptual prominence determine the direction of asymmetries in similarity judgments; there was little support for the salience mechanism in model fits. The best quantum model was shown to outperform the distance-based, pointwise geometric model of similarity judgments, even when that approach was augmented to incorporate a parameter that allowed for symmetry violations (as in Nosofsky, 1991). More recently, Tsuchiya et al. (in press) suggested that results such as those from indicate that the basic elements of consciousness, qualia, should be understood using quantum theory, rather than the existing formalisms.

Regarding violations of the triangle inequality, different regions in a quantum space are associated with different contexts (e.g., features/ concepts). So, using Tversky's (1977) example, if a region of a quantum space is consistent with the property of Communism, then representations in or close to that region would reflect varying degrees of consistency with Communism. Therefore, if basis sets are arranged in a two-dimensional space so that one region reflects Cuba, sandwiched between a region for Russia and one for Jamaica, it is straightforward to see how triangle inequality violations can occur (at least on dissimilarities).

Coverage of the diagnosticity effect relies on order effects in non-commuting projectors. assumed that each possible pairwise similarity was computed with the quantum similarity rule but modified to include prior projections to any context stimuli. So, in a sequence of projections involving both the compared stimuli and the context ones, differences in eventual selection were observed consistent with the diagnosticity effect. A more recent quantum model for diagnosticity was reported by Yearsley et al. (2022). They assumed that the quantum process for similarity judgments is potentially modified by a series of thoughts which are potentially focusing (if the projection sequence retains a transition between the items which are meant to be compared) or distracting. They fitted the model to data on similarity judgments from two experiments.

Regarding similarity comparisons sensitive to structure, Pothos and Trueblood (2015) adapted the quantum similarity model using the idea of Smolensky (1990) for structure in linguistic representations based on tensor products. For example, for stimuli having three parts (top, middle, bottom), such that each part can differ in color and shape, we can write a representation vector as | âªâ¨| â âªâ¨| âª + | âªâ¨| â âªâ¨| âª + | âªâ¨| â âªâ¨| âª. The 'part' vectors keep track of matching parts (and can be adjusted to capture influence from matches in place or matches out of place, Goldstone, 1994; Equation 7). In this way, the quantum geometric model of similarity is consistent with the approaches of the previously distinct geometric and feature-based/alignment models, while also accounting for structural similarity as in alignment models.

Critical evaluation and controversy. Some of the assumptions of quantum similarity models are questionable. Pothos et al.'s (2013) assumption of a mental state that is neutral in relation to the compared stimuli was justified as one of uniformed priors, appropriate for comparisons involving conceptual stimuli. By contrast allowed for a biased mental state, with the justification that in perceptual processing it is not uncommon to have priming or other biasing effects, such as recency, primacy etc. However, in principle, some of these effects might be applicable for conceptual stimuli too (e.g., Hogarth & Einhorn, 1992), questioning the assumption of a neutral mental state in . More work is needed in this direction, including relevant empirical data.

The diagnosticity effect explanation in has the following difficulty. The explanation relies on how the comparison between the same two stimuli can be different, depending on differences in prior projections (assumed to correspond to contextual stimuli). However, there is an issue of scalability when dealing with multiple contextual items and how to understand comparisons involving different numbers of context stimuli. Yearsley et al. (2022) offered an account of diagnosticity which eliminates this problem, since any processing corresponding to contextual items only introduces one additional step in the projection sequence.

Another problem is that some of the quantum similarity proposals are descriptive. For example, Pothos and Trueblood's (2015) proposal for structural similarity consisted of showing how structural similarity could be embodied in the quantum similarity framework. Arguably, the main value of this work is in showing how structural proposals in language (as in Smolensky, 1990) and in similarity can be analogous.

Critics can also challenge the assumption that, in quantum similarity models, concepts are assumed to be incompatible. This means, for example, that we cannot 'concurrently' think of two concepts, like Korea and China. The rationale for this assumption is that thinking about two concepts (e.g., for evaluating their similarity) is a sequential process and a train of thought, so that successive projections correspond to the mental state going through different concepts. Depending on which concept is currently considered, incompatibility means that there are differing perspectives on the likelihood of thinking about other concepts. For example, if one is thinking about China there is uncertainty about whether he/she will next think about Korea, depending on the relation between the subspaces. However, currently it is difficult to reconcile this picture with situations when the compared stimuli are presented concurrently and have simple perceptual form. Such difficulties indicate that the quantum approach to similarity is incomplete.

Quantum similarity researchers have argued that the main advantage of their approach is the completeness of coverage of Tversky's (1977) and related results, when compared to that from other predominant approaches. For example, the main issue with Tversky's (1977) contrast model is that it involves two independent parameters.
