For violations of symmetry, these had to be set in a circumvented way (based on assumptions about the relative weighting of the features of the subject and the referent in a similarity comparison). The situation is analogous with other well-known accounts of similarity. For example, Krumhansl's (1978Krumhansl's ( , 1988) distance-density model involves a somewhat post hoc approach concerning asymmetries, since adequate coverage requires the assumption that China is similar to more other countries than Korea. Additionally, regarding the triangle inequality, the model incorporates a mechanism of computing similarity within reduced subspaces, corresponding to different contexts, but this is underspecified (e.g., how to determine such subspaces). For symmetry, Ashby and Perrin's (1988) General Recognition Theory required an assumption of how many other counties are similar to Korea vs. China opposite to that of Krumhansl (1978)[1]. Also, for violations of the triangle inequality, inequivalent perceptual distributions were required for Russia, Jamaica, and Cuba, and there are no a priori reasons to anticipate such an assumption.

Some researchers have considered variants to the quantum similarity model, intended to capture its essential characteristics. For example, Kintsch (2014) proposed a similarity model based on Latent Semantic Analysis (LSA) that he argued shares properties with the quantum similarity model. Specifically, Kintsch employed the idea that the similarity between words can be computed based on the cosine of corresponding word vectors, where the vector representations (angles, lengths) are based on LSA computations. For example, for two objects A, B, we would have

. He suggested that the length of a vector in an LSA space reflects amount of knowledge and it is this feature of the model which allows asymmetries in similarity (since the numerator of the similarity metric invokes only one of the compared items). However, there is some underspecificity regarding the kind of knowledge implied by differences in length. By contrast, in e.g. Tversky's (1977) model or the quantum similarity model additional knowledge is directly reflected in, respectively, additional features or additional dimensions in corresponding subspaces.

Has there been any generative value from quantum similarity models? showed that primacy versus recency drive similarity asymmetries in simple, perceptual stimuli, instead of their perceptual properties (e.g., how focal different colors are, as assumed by Tversky, 1977). While the idea of primacy vs. recency is not new, quantum theory offered a framework which allowed a fairly natural test of this idea in the case of similarity judgments. Yearsley et al. (2021) also predicted a tradeoff between diagnosticity and the converse effect of attraction, whereby given two stimuli equidistant to a target, a stimulus just dominating another one would be preferred. Yearsley et al. reported empirical results successfully fitted by the quantum model. Finally, Tsuchiya et al.'s (in press) work is an ambitious attempt to extend quantum cognition to the study of consciousness. They adopted the formalism of instruments, which is a sophisticated way to specify the measurement interaction as a dynamical process. This allows some flexibility in what the impact of measurement is. For example, it could be that the state identifies with the question outcome or with the opposite outcome etc. (Ozawa & Khrennikov, 2021). While there are many intriguing implications from such an approach, more empirical work is needed, before its promise can be realized.

div.head: Order effects on judgments
div.p: Empirical research. There is abundant evidence for order effects in decision making. For example, in a well-known investigation based on a public opinion Gallup poll, the probability to answer yes to a question about whether Clinton is trustworthy depended on whether an analogous question about Gore preceded or followed the Clinton one (Moore, 2002;Tourangeau, Rips, & Rasinski, 2000). There are similar results in medical diagnosis, whereby the assessment for the probability of a disease depended on the order of conditionalizing evidence, even for medical trainees (Bergus et al., 1998), and in a jury decision task assessments of guilt depended on the order of defense and prosecutor presentations (McKenzie, Lee, & Chen, 2002;. Moreover, evaluations of persuasive messages, such as public service announcements, depend on whether the message is evaluated from the perspective of the self first (self-then-others) or from the perspective of others first (others-thenself; . Question order effects can be categorized as primacy vs. recency effects, contrast vs. assimilation effects, or additive vs. subtractive effects, referring to the various ways questions or pieces of evidence interact/ combine (Hogarth & Einhorn, 1992;Moore, 2002;Payne et al., 1993;.

One of the most powerful predictions generated from the quantum cognition research program is the Quantum Question (QQ) equality . The QQ equality provides an a priori, parameter-free prediction which constrains people's response probabilities to two, binary-choice questions. To see how this equality works, let A and B be two questions, where individuals can either respond 'Yes ' or 'No' to Wang et al. (2014) evaluated the QQ equality using 70 national surveys in the US and reported that generally the constraint imposed by this equality was obeyed.

A second type of invariant relation concerns order effects on inference (Yearsley & Trueblood, 2018). Consider asking judgments about the likelihood of a hypothesis H after presenting two different pieces of evidence (A, B) in different orders (e.g., evaluate H after first being informed that A is true and then being informed that B is not true). This design allows one to estimate the following Q statistic:
Using an experiment with 1200 participants, Yearsley and Trueblood (2018) found this Q statistic to be close to zero.

As noted above, Yearsley and Trueblood (2018) provided a novel test of the co-occurrence between order effects and conjunction fallacies, which contrasts with the null result of Boyer et al. (2016). To test the prediction of the QQ equality on inference, Yearsley and Trueblood (2018) collected judgments regarding five main candidates for the Republican and Democratic 2016 presidential nominations, concerning (1) the probability of a single event (e.g., the likelihood of one of the candidates winning a state primary) (2) the probability of a single event conditioned on either one or the conjunction of two events (e.g., the likelihood of a candidate winning the election given that they won a state primary or the likelihood of a candidate winning a state primary and winning the election). As there are two possible order effects comparisons per candidate and five total candidates, there were ten potential order effect comparisons. The Bayes Factor for all ten comparisons was greater than 10 14 , which strongly suggests the presence of order effects for each comparison. Next, for each candidate, each participant judged eight different conjunctions. Therefore, since there were five different candidates, there were 40 comparisons that could give rise to the conjunction fallacy. The Bayes factor for 37 out of the 40 comparisons had BF10 > 12, which again strongly suggests the presence of conjunction fallacies. Importantly, both effects were observed for the majority of participants. They also observed a dependence of style of thinking on the likelihood of incompatible representations, so that more compatible representations were more likely for participants adopting a more analytic mode of reasoning (Frederick, 2005).

This finding was also corroborated by , who compared order effects in categorization judgments, in situations which were rule-based (RB) vs. information-integration (II) ones. In Epping and Busemeyer, each participant learned to categorize simple, perceptual stimuli into two categories, and then, during a transfer phase, rated the likelihood that a stimulus belonged to one category and then rated the likelihood that the stimulus belonged to the other category. The RB categorization strategy relies on participants using some verbalizeable rule, which favors a more analytical style of thinking. By contrast, the II categorization strategy is assumed to be mediated via the basal ganglia procedural learning system. Procedural knowledge is generally assumed to be less accessible to consciousness and reflecting a more intuitive style of thinking. In line with Yearsley and Trueblood (2018), reported that the order effects in likelihood ratings were significant in the II task, but not so in the RB one.

Question order effects have also been examined using a series of three binary questions, with the so-called ABA paradigm (Khrennikov, Basieva, Dzhafarov, & Busemeyer, 2014). Suppose that order effects are first found to occur for questions A and B in an initial experiment. Then, in a subsequent experiment, question A is presented, followed by B, followed by A again. Busemeyer and Wang (2017) conducted this ABA experiment with 325 participants on sets of questions for which order effects had been previously identified and they found a moderate amount of opinion change between the first and second iteration of the A question.
Quantum cognitive models. According to quantum theory, the basic explanation for question order effects is non-commutativity of incompatible questions:
div.formula: [ ;,H â (I^= a #( %; | â©a " differs from [ (I â ;,H^= a %; #( | â©a "
div.p: . For example, for incompatible questions, earlier questions may create a perspective or context which impacts the way later questions are understood. Specific empirical findings on order effects have been described using more complex (e.g., dynamical) quantum models, considered below.

Trueblood and Busemeyer (2011) developed a quantum model of order effects on inference and tested the model by fitting it to data from Bergus et al.'s (1998) Bergus et al.'s (1998) task, they specified a mental state for the possible combinations between the presence or absence of a disease and positive or negative evidence of a disease in a four-dimensional, composite vectors space. The initial story and subsequent pieces of evidence were modeled with different rotations of this mental state, where, cognitively, rotations represent the change of perspectives. The mental state was constructed from a part corresponding to the hypothesis of whether the disease was present or not and one corresponding to the evidence. The decision process was modeled as dynamical evolution of this mental state, and occurred both for each part of the mental state separately and in a way which mixed the parts together (this model is analogous to that of Pothos & Busemeyer, 2009, disjunction effect and will be further considered below).

Beyond binary questions, Wang and Busemeyer (2015; see also Wang & Busemeyer, 2016a) developed a quantum random walk model for modeling question order effects for questions answered by rating scales (e.g., a 9-point rating scale). They successfully applied their model to order results concerning the effectiveness of public health service announcements from the perspective of the self and then another person, in this order vs. the reverse order. This model is analogous to the one Kvam et al. (2015) employed to model the interference between intermediate decisions and later confidence ratings (see section on "Measurement and interference effects on judgments and decisions") and the one employed to model order effects on category judgments for perceptual stimuli. Wang et al. (2014; showed that the QQ equality can be derived from quantum theory with minimal assumptions, notably, it is valid regardless of the dimensionality of the subspaces for each event and the overall space. In two dimensions, the QQ equality relates to the way the positive and negative answers for two questions (two different basis sets in Hilbert space) are linked up -the unitary rotation that takes us from the basis set for one question to that of another is fixed by the relation between any one answer to one question and another to the other question. Wang et al. (2014) also considered when we expect the QQ equality to be violated, notably when new information is introduced after each question. Specifically, a key assumption underlying the derivation of the QQ equality is that starting from a common state (technically, the state is represented by a density matrix for a mixture of people with individual differences), questions are asked back to back without any information inserted in between so that two successive projections are applied (either % # or # % ) to the common state. New information presented before or inserted in between questions would change the state in different ways. For example, if new information is presented in between questions, then a change is produced by a transformation U' for one type of information, and a different change is produced by another transformation U'' for a different type of information. Rather than comparing % # with # % (as required for the derivation of the QQ equality), we are now comparing % â²â² # with # â² % , and the equality is no longer expected to hold. For example, the Rose-Jackson poll in Table 1 violated this condition for the QQ test. A more complex quantum model that includes transformations U' and U'' is required for this case. Note, Yearsley and Trueblood's (2018) QQ equality variant requires one-dimensional subspaces and reciprocity (reciprocity is automatically true when A, B are represented by one-dimensional subspaces). Yearsley and Trueblood's (2018;Boyer-Kassem et al., 2016) proposal that incompatibility is the driving factor for both order effects and conjunction fallacies was accompanied by a simple quantum model with one-dimensional subspaces for the effects of interest. The model was employed to extract constraints on the predicted size of order effects and the degree to which conjunction fallacies occur. Also, by studying individual differences in thinking using the Cognitive Reflection Task (CRT; Frederick, 2005), Yearsley and Trueblood linked an analytic style of thinking with more compatible representations, using a hierarchical model of representations, from fully quantum to fully classical, with intermediate representations having a hybrid form (from Trueblood, Yearsley, & Pothos, 2017). further explored how a quantum approach can be used to formalize the analytic, intuitive distinction, in their categorization work. They argued that RB categorizations allow people to ground category judgments in a single basis, corresponding to that of the relevant stimulus feature measured with the verbalizable rule. In the II case, people cannot use stimulus features to construct a compatible basis for the two category decisions and are left with incompatible representations. This is how they explained order effects in sequential judgments with II categorizations, but not RB ones.

In the ABA paradigm, the correlation between the two responses of A should reveal identity when A, B are compatible, but it would be otherwise bounded depending on the uncertainty relation between A, B (Khrennikov et al., 2014). That is, if a response to question A is followed by an incompatible question B, then the answer to question A has to become uncertain again and the correlation between the two A copies should be less than 1. The same model for question order effects of Wang and Busemeyer (2015) was employed in the ABA case too (Busemeyer & Wang, 2017) and predicted that the amount of change between the first and second A question should be a decreasing function of the correlation between the answers to the A, B questions.

Although that AB vs BA paradigm offers a convenient way to identify order effects in judgment or inference, the ABA paradigm allows for simultaneous evaluation of the question order effect and the response replicability effect. These two effects can each be described by quantum measurement theory individually, but not simultaneously (Khrennikov et al., 2014). To address this, Ozawa and Khrennikov (2020) developed a more general form of quantum measurement theory based on the theory of quantum instruments. A quantum instrument is a mathematical object intended to replace the traditional projectors in quantum theory, in a way which affords more flexibility and emphasizes the interaction between the quantum system being measured and the classical instrument being used to it. By incorporating quantum instruments, the more general model is intended to capture the statistical properties of all physically realizable quantum measurements.

Critical evaluation and controversy. Question order effects are classically puzzling, because of commutativity in conjunction. Suppose A, B represent the answer yes to corresponding questions. Then, the event answering yes to the first question and then yes to the second one is given by ( ) ( | ) = ( & ) = ( ) ( | ) and so accommodating order effects can only be done by conditionalizing on e.g. order. Social psychologists argue that sometimes answers to questions are not simply retrieved from memory, but instead they are constructed on-line, which can produce order effects, which, for example, might be the case if earlier questions allow unique thoughts and perspectives for later ones (Schwarz, 2007). Hogarth and Einhorn's (1992) 2002and concluded that the quantum model provided the better fit to empirical results.

Regarding non-binary questions, Wang and Busemeyer (2015) compared their quantum model with a closely matched Markov random walk model (both models required estimating five parameters to predict 182 joint frequencies from both orders) and reported superior fits for the quantum model for their empirical results. This was largely because in the quantum model the two questions were represented as incompatible, so that in consecutive judgments order/ interference effects can emerge; this was not possible in the Markov random walk model.

The QQ equality is one of the most impressive predictions from the quantum cognition research programme, because it represents an a priori, parameter-free prediction, which can be derived with minimal assumptions. Some researchers have attempted to derive the QQ equality with non-quantum accounts. Kellen et al. (2018) and identified approaches that either reproduced the QQ equality exactly or showed the QQ equality as a likely prediction, thus contesting the necessity for the quantum formalism to account for the QQ equality. These alternative models have an advantage in that the underlying psychological process is more clearly specified. However, one can argue that it is unsurprising that heuristic principles can be employed to reproduce a formal result; descriptive accounts for an empirical finding are always possible. The advantage of the quantum approach is that the QQ equality is predicted a priori and enables a clear characterization of the conditions under which we expect the prediction to fail. Note, additionally, it is unclear whether Kellen et al.'s (2018) analysis can naturally be extended to reproduce the QQ equality variant that Yearsley and Trueblood (2018) reported.

In Yearsley and Trueblood's (2018) work, both the co-occurrence of order effects with conjunction fallacies (and the size of these effects) and the likelihood of having incompatible representations on style of thinking (analytic vs. reflective) were a priori predictions motivated from quantum theory, which were confirmed. Yearsley and Trueblood (2018) examined whether Hogarth and Einhorn's (1992) anchoring and adjustment model can reproduce their QQ equality variant, but this was not possible without implausible assumptions. They also considered Costello and Watts's (2014) probability theory plus noise model for the conjunction fallacy, but they derived a constraint from this theory not satisfied by their data. They noted that there are no existing non-quantum models which require a co-occurrence of order effects and conjunction fallacies or that predict a dependency of such effects on cognitive style of thinking. prediction that RB categorizations indicate compatible representations (and analogously for II ones) is a bold one which merits further tests.

The ABA paradigm was proposed as a test of the incompatibility principle as an explanation for question order effects (Khrennikov et al. (2014). The correlation between the two responses of A in the ABA paradigm should reveal identity when A, B are compatible, but if they are incompatible, it should be bounded depending on the uncertainty relation between A, B (Khrennikov et al., 2014). That is, if a response to question A is followed by an incompatible question B, then the answer to question A has to become uncertain again and the correlation between the two A copies should be less than 1. Khrennikov et al. (2014) argued that people would try to be consistent across the replications of A, regardless of the presence of B in between and despite the fact that there may be order effects for the A, B questions. However, the results of the ABA experiment by Wang and Busemeyer (2015) showed changes in opinion across the replications of question A and, more importantly, the squared correlation between the first and second A measurements was found to be positively related to the squared correlation between the A, B measurements, as predicted by their quantum model. Classical test theory (e.g., Lord & Novick, 2013) also postulates variability in measurements across occasions. According to this view, the measurement outcome from rating a question represents both a true opinion, that is fixed across repeated measurements, and some measurement error, that randomly varies across repeated measurements. However, the measurement error model differs from the quantum approach in a fundamental manner. When considering an AA sequence (i.e., responding to A twice without B in between), the projection principle of quantum probability predicts perfect correlation between the first and second measurements of A, whereas classical test theory allows measurement error to occur across repetitions [2]. Classical test theory also cannot predict the role of compatibility of B in affecting the relation between the two iterations of A in an ABA sequence. Finally, Ozawa and Khrennikov (2021) argued that question order effects and the QQ equality should co-occur with what they called the response replicability effect, that is, identity between the two iterations of the same question A. In order to produce all three effects, they employed the formalism of instruments regarding measurements, which allows more flexibility, compared to the standard approach (the standard approach being that post-measurement the state identifies with the outcome of the measurement). However, it is unclear whether the empirical data favor Ozawa and Khrennikov's assumption of the response replicability effect, as just discussed .

div.head: Causal inference
div.p: This section explores how quantum models can explain causal inference, that is, inference influenced by knowledge about causal relationships of events. Empirical research. presented three experiments, broadly based on the causal structures and procedures from Rehder (2014), seeking to challenge classical intuition in causal inference. They reported three novel empirical findings. First, they observed evidence for reciprocity, that is, ( | ) = ( | ), which is surprising because of the asymmetry between causes and effects (reciprocity shows insensitivity in causal direction). The inverse fallacy (Kahneman & Tversky, 1972) is related to reciprocity, but there have not been demonstrations in the area of causal inference. Second, there was evidence for memorylessness, which occurs when conditionalization in probability estimation depends only on the latest information to be considered. For example, in some cases conditionalization on A & then B would appear equivalent to just B. Finally, they observed evidence that classical inconsistencies were more likely to be adopted in unfamiliar situations and for participants who approached the task in a more intuitive way (as opposed to deliberative, measured using the Cognitive Reflection Test; Frederick, 2005). Together with these novel empirical findings, also reported violations of the Markov condition, anti-discounting behavior, and order effects, partly replicating Rehder (2014).

div.head: Quantum cognitive models.
div.p: The evidence for inconsistencies with classical probability principles in causal inference motivates the application of quantum theory. Equally, there is evidence for some classical behavior in causal inference (Rehder, 2014). Accordingly, Trueblood et al. (2017) specified a hierarchy of representations, from fully quantum to fully classical, which included intermediate levels with some effects/ causes represented in compatible ways and some in incompatible ways. The fully classical representation required an eight-dimensional space, since all causal reasoning scenarios involved three binary variables, while the fully quantum representation required only a two-dimensional space (cf. Trueblood & Busemeyer, 2012). The advantage of the hierarchical approach was that quantum and classical putative influences could be integrated in the same framework in a coherent manner. Regarding the quantum part of the model, different causes, effects were represented as rays and rotation matrices were fitted to the data to achieve empirical fits. Probabilities were computed by projectors in nearly all cases, except for the fully quantum one, for which a version with POVMs outperformed a version with projectors. In modeling, POVMs allowed the circumvention of reciprocity (which was not observed consistently).

Critical evaluation and controversy. employed model comparison techniques penalizing for a number of parameters and so determined the dimension of the model needed to predict the data for each experiment, noting that the highest dimensional version was equivalent to a classical probability model. In all cases, a dimensionality below fully classical was required for best fit (i.e., quantum representations were needed). Prior to Trueblood et a.'s (2017) work, it had already been recognized that causal inference can violate classical principles, which undermined the then predominant descriptive and normative framework for causal reasoning, based on Bayesian networks (Pearl, 1988). Rehder's (2014) results provided strong evidence that, at least in some cases, there is a discrepancy between predictions from Bayes nets and human behavior (see also Fernbach & Sloman, 2009;Park & Sloman, 2013;Rottman & Hastie, 2016). Rehder's (2014) approach for the range of behaviors in causal inference, including both classical and non-classical biases, was to specify three heuristic models, which together with a Bayesian one could additively combine to predict participant behavior. argued that their main contribution was to show how individual heuristic principles were not needed, but rather nonclassical behavior in causal inference could be explained by employing incompatibility/ interference effects from quantum theory (see also Mistry et al., 2018). Note, even if there is no technical need for separate heuristics, heuristics potentially provide descriptive interpretations for subsets of the relevant behavior under quantum theory (Mistry et al., 2018). Also, showed that more compatible representations were more likely to be observed for participants adopting a more analytic mode of reasoning (Frederick, 2005) and after more experience with the task, so supporting their view for the source of incompatibility in cognition.

Despite the potential benefits of a quantum approach in addressing apparent Bayesian fallacies in causal inference, there are also some challenges to be addressed. First, there is an abundant amount of evidence (Lewis, 1970;Pearl, 2009;Morgan & Winship, 2015;Sloman et al., 2015) that, beyond observational-level Bayesian inference processes, counterfactual reasoning plays an important role in human causal inference. However, there has not been any work on a quantum approach concerning counterfactual reasoning and the connection from counterfactual to causation. Second, a recent study on causal reasoning has included a focus on the intuitive physics domain (White, 2006;Wolff et al., 2007;Gerstenberg et al., 2012Gerstenberg et al., , 2021; models that try to explain causal reasoning in the physical domain usually rely on mental physical simulations. It is unclear how quantum probability can be integrated into intuitive reasoning about physical domains, where mental simulation is explicit.

div.head: The disjunction effect in decision making
div.p: Empirical research. The disjunction effect is an influential demonstration of an apparent violation of the law of total probability, which is defined here as the failure of total probability inferred from known conditions to predict the probability of an unknown condition. In one variant , participants were presented with a prisoner's dilemma game in which the dominant action is defection for both players. The unique feature of the experiment by Shafir and Tversky (1992) was that participants received different information about the action of the other player: that he/she would cooperate, defect, or no information. In each of the 'known action' conditions, most participants preferred to defect, but in the 'unknown' condition, many reversed their judgment to cooperate, revealing that ( ; ) < ( | ) and at the same time ( ; ) < ( | ), where the conditional refers to information provided by the experimenter for the other player, and ( ; ) refers to the probability when there is no such information. Given that there are only two actions the opponent can adopt (defect or cooperate), the total probability to defect when the opponent's action is unknown should be equal to

). Therefore, the marginal in the unknown condition is expected to be bounded by the conditionals in each of the known conditions, but the results violate these bounds, and so have been interpreted as a violation of the law of total probability. The original finding was replicated by Croson (1999), Busemeyer, Wang, Matthew (2009) and Tesar (in press).

A similar finding was observed with a two-stage gambling task . Participants first played an initial gamble that could result in a win of $200 or a loss of $100 (hypothetically), and then they were asked if they wished to play a second time. This experiment again included three conditions in which participants received different information about the first stage gamble: that he/she won, lost, or no information. As above, in each of the 'known outcome' conditions, participants preferred to play again, but in the 'unknown' condition many reversed their preference and chose to not play again. Note, Kuhberger, Komunska, and Perner (2001) did not replicate this effect, but a more recent study (Broekaert, Busemeyer & Pothos, 2020) shows that the more risk averse individuals show this effect while the less risk averse ones do not. Broekaert et al. (2020) further reported an order effect in relation to the disjunction effect, which offers additional motivation to the use of quantum models, as such models require an order effect to produce disjunction fallacies.

Quantum cognitive models. Pothos and Busemeyer (2009) and Busemeyer et al. (2006) proposed a dynamical model for the prisoner dilemma version of the disjunction effect. The model is built from two different parts. In the first part, each action (defect, cooperate) of the opponent is represented by a separate Hamiltonian, 8 ( ), 9 ( ), based on the payoff matrix of the game. The two Hamiltonians can be combined by a direct sum to produce 8 ( ) â 9 ( ). If only this first part is used, then the predictions satisfy the law of total probability. To produce interference effects, Pothos and Busemeyer (2009) used an additional interaction Hamiltonian J(K which was designed to align beliefs and actions, in a manner consistent with the psychological principle of cognitive dissonance (Festinger, 1957). Using both parts together, ( 8 â 9 ) + J(K , can lead to interference effects that account for the observed violations of the law of total probability (Equation 8). Broekaert et al. (2020) proposed a similar model using analogous unitary dynamics, except that their model was developed to explain the disjunction effect in gambling task. Accordingly, their Hamiltonian and measurement matrices would be a little different from those of Pothos and Busemeyer (2009). Note, because there were differences in the emergence of the disjunction effect between less and more risk averse participants, the model was fitted differently for the two groups. Aerts (2009), Khrennikov and Haven (2009), and Yukalov and Sornette (2011) all provided alternative quantum models based on the common idea that the quantum state under the uncertain condition is a superposition of the quantum states for each known condition: L2*;,M(0IN( = â¢ L2*;,O'( + â¢ L2*;,&IH, . The squared length of this superposition state could produce an interference term, â, like that shown in Equation 2, which is required to cover the disjunction effect.

Critical evaluation and controversy. Pothos and Busemeyer (2009) showed that the quantum model could describe the disjunction effect better than a matched Markov model (employing the Kolmogorov forward equation). The initial explanation for the disjunction effect, from Tversky and Shafir (1992), was that this is a failure of consequential reasoning. In prisoner's dilemma participants may have a good reason to defect knowing the opponent has defected and a good (different) reason knowing the opponent has cooperated but lack clarity of why they should defect in the unknown case. However, this intuitive explanation does not provide quantitative predictions. Tversky and Shafir (1992) proposed a version of prospect theory with a changing reference point to account for the disjunction effect with the two-stage gambling task. But the changing reference point model only applies to results from that task and not to prisoner's dilemma, whereas the quantum model applies to both sets of results using the same principles. One criticism of Pothos and Busemeyer's (2009) model is that, because of its use of unitary dynamics, the choice probabilities can oscillate over extended time periods. Pothos and Busemeyer (2009) based their predictions on a point in the dynamics before oscillations occurred, but a better approach might be to use open system dynamics, in which oscillations are eventually quenched (e.g., Asano et al., 2011aAsano et al., , 2011bKvam et al., 2021;Rosner et al., 2022).

It has been argued that perhaps the ability of quantum models to account for puzzling findings like the disjunction effect arises from the additional flexibility of the quantum model produced by extra parameters or model complexity. To address this issue, Busemeyer, Wang, and Shiffrin (2015) conducted a Bayesian model comparison of the Pothos and Busemeyer (2009) quantum model with the Tversky and Shafir (1992) reference point model for the two-stage gambling paradigm. A large experiment on the two-stage gambling task was used to compare the two models, which were matched in their number of free parameters. The Bayes factors were computed at the individual participant level, and the model comparison overwhelmingly favored the quantum model, indicating that its success is due to its ability to make accurate predictions rather than increased complexity. Despite this, a comparison between a non-dynamic quantum model and an open system model (which avoids the problem of indefinite oscillations) has yet to be conducted for the disjunction fallacy.

Yukalov and Sornette's (2011) framework was presented as a general framework for probabilistic decision making, with applications to a variety of decision-making phenomena (also discussed later). However, regarding the disjunction effect, there is a weakness. They proposed that the interference term is determined by an uncertainty factor that is negative for taking actions, and positive for not taking actions. This principle applies to the two-stage gambling results, but not to the prisoner's dilemma results. In the latter, both cooperation and defection are actions that the player can take. Aerts (2009) applied his conceptual combination model to the disjunction effect as well. The two concepts in the original version of the model were equated with the various conditions required for testing the sure thing principle. This creates a confusing picture, since in conceptual combination we have â ( & ) = [ â ( ), â ( )^. However, for the disjunction effect we must instead consider ( ) = ( & ) + ( & ) (plus possibly interference terms). A more recent problem regarding models of disjunction fallacy is evident in Broekaert et al. (2020), where findings show the extent of risk aversion is closely correlated with the fallacy in the gambling setting, while none of the current models take into account risk as an explicit feature. The quantum model provided best fit to the data for both more risk averse and less risk averse participants, but the fits were obtained by utilizing two different sets of parameters (for the low and high risk conditions), rather than directly taking into account risk, as is the case with the existing Markov and logistic models. A future direction would be to extend quantum models for gambling tasks in a way that include risk and loss aversion directly.

div.head: Measurement and interference effects on judgments and decisions
div.p: Empirical research. Humans are very sensitive to measurements, e.g., requests for decisions or opinions. Asking for an opinion, or a judgment, or a decision can alter a person's underlying mental state and change their future behavior (Brehm, 1956;Lichtenstein & Slovic, 2006;Schwarz, 2007;Sharot et al., 2010;Sherman, 1980;Feldman & Lynch, 1988). There have been several proposals for how earlier questions might influence responses to later ones. When discussing question order effects, we considered the idea that earlier questions might create thoughts which impact on how later ones are approached -but such effects are not specific to whether a question is considered but not answered vs. answered. Regarding the latter, answering a question in a certain way might bias subsequent responding, as a way to avoid cognitive dissonance (Festinger, 1957). For example, GlÃ¶ckner, Betsch, and Schindler (2010) demonstrated coherence shifts, i.e. changes in subjective cue validities related to a decision, in a direction indicating greater consistency with the decision. Similar results were reported in (hypothetical) legal decision making (Holyoak & Simon, 1999;Simon et al., 2001). There have been some studies attempting to harness such intuitions into paradigms suitable for applications of quantum theory. White et al. (2014 provided a direct demonstration of constructive influences in judgment, as predicted by a quantum framework. They employed a paradigm of presenting two stimuli of opposite positive, negative valence (e.g., corresponding to imagined smartphone ads). The pairs of stimuli were always presented in the same order. In all cases participants provided an affective rating for the second stimulus. In some cases, participants provided an affective rating for the first one as well. White et al. (2014 observed what they called an evaluation bias, according to which the second stimulus was rated in a more extreme way when the first stimulus had been rated too, than when it had not. Put differently, the intermediate judgment created an impression of greater contrast between the first and second stimuli. White et al. (2014 presented several modifications to their procedure and controls and generalized the finding with other kinds of judgments (e.g., trustworthiness). In a more recent demonstration, White et al. (2020) showed a similar effect, in the context of a real organizational questionnaire, with participants comprised of business managers taking part in organizational workshops.

The idea that judgments can influence the mental state of a person was further explored by Yearsley and Pothos (2016). They employed a hypothetical murder mystery, such that the suspect would be originally considered innocent. All participants would then receive 12 pieces of evidence indicating the suspect to be guilty, such that each piece of evidence was individually weak but collectively they would make a strong case of guilt. With a between participants manipulation, Yearsley and Pothos (2016) varied the number of intermediate judgments about guilt for the suspect. They found that increasing the number of intermediate judgments slowed down opinion change. Note, this is the quantum Zeno prediction in physical systems, as translated to opinion change.

An interference effect of categorization on decision making has been found using a categorization-decision task (Townsend et al., 2000;Busemeyer et al., 2009, Wang & Busemeyer, 2016. Participants were first presented with a face and then went through one of two conditions on each trial. For the categorization-decision condition, participants were asked to first categorize the face as friendly or hostile, and then decide to attack or withdraw; for the decision alone condition, participants observed the face without being asked to categorize it and simply made a decision. This paradigm provides an empirical test of the law of total probability. That is, is the sum ( & ) + ( &~) from the categorization-decision condition equal to ( ; ) from the decision alone condition? The intermediate categorization apparently produced interference effects on the decision: the probability to attack in the decision alone condition was higher than both when the face was categorized as friendly and hostile. A similar design was used by Kvam et al. (2015) to investigate interference effects of choice on later confidence ratings. Participants were presented with a dynamic dot display (dots jiggling around with some proportion systematically moving in the same direction) and then received one of two conditions on each trial. For the choice-judge condition, participants were asked to first decide the direction of dot motion at time t1, and then rate their confidence that the direction was left vs. right at a later time t2; for the judgment alone condition, participants simply pushed a preplanned button at time t1, and then made a judgment at time t2. This paradigm provides an empirical test of the law of total probability and it was found that the intermediate choice produced interference effects on the later judgment. The average confidence rating was stronger for the correct direction under the judgment alone condition as compared to the total probability from the choice-judgment condition. Kvam et al. (2014) also examined measurement effects in a prisoner's dilemma task. In such a task, participants have to decide whether to defect or cooperate with a (usually computer) agent, and then a payoff is assigned to different combinations of actions that encourage mutual defection. Kvam et al. (2014) employed an added manipulation in which the player first made a promise to cooperate or not to a first agent (A), and then played the PD game with another agent (B). They found that the promise made to a first agent A increased cooperation rate for another agent B, contrary to economic game theory.

Finally, interference effects of belief judgments on decisions have also been observed in a sequential prisoner's dilemma task (Blanco et al., 2014;Croson, 1999;Tesar, in press). Asking a person to predict the opponent's play changes the player's probability to cooperate as compared to conditions when no prediction is made.

Quantum cognitive models. White et al.'s (2014White et al.'s ( , 2015 quantum model for the evaluation bias was based on a two-dimensional space, with a basis for positive, negative affect and an initial state close to one of these rays, depending on the valence of the first stimulus (e.g., if the first stimulus was positive, the mental state was close to the positive affect ray). The subsequent oppositely valenced stimulus was modeled with an appropriate rotation (e.g., if the subsequent stimulus was negative, the rotation was towards the negative ray). The impact of the intermediate rating was a projection of the mental state to the corresponding subspace, which meant that the subsequent rotation would bring the mental state closer to the oppositely valenced ray. Therefore, the collapse assumption in quantum theory drives prediction. Yearsley and Pothos (2016) also employed a two-dimensional space, with a basis set corresponding to the guilt, innocence of the suspect. The effect of each piece of evidence on the mental state was modeled by a time-dependent unitary operator, so that the impact of particular pieces of evidence on opinion change depended on their serial position (Hogarth & Einhorn, 1992). Intermediate judgments on the mental state were modeled through POVMs, since with several judgments (in some conditions) there would be large aggregate error. Yearsley and Pothos (2016) computed an analytic expression for the survival probability (probability of no-change) as a function of intermediate judgments. The main feature of their quantum model is the collapse postulate.

For the categorization-decision task, Wang and Busemeyer (2016b) used a model similar to that of Pothos and Busemeyer (2009). They also employed a Hamiltonian with two parts: one part built using the structure !P',()2; â¨ QIHK'2, , corresponding to changes in payoff evaluations depending on each kind of categorization, and another part using an interaction Hamiltonian, which aligns categorizations with decisions. The full Hamiltonian is !P',()2; â¨ QIHK'2, + R':,P , which allows dynamical evolution of the mental state in a way that produces interference effects and violations of the law of total probability.

These results were modeled in an alternative way by Moreira and Wichert (2016), who employed Tucci's (1995) quantum-like network. While Bayesian networks propagate probabilities, quantum-like networks propagate amplitudes. Because amplitudes propagate across multiple paths, quantum nets can give rise to interference effects not possible in Bayesian networks. Moreira and Wichert (2016) computed the interference terms in their quantum network from the face images in the categorization, decision paradigm (from Busemeyer et al., 2009). They converted the images into vectors, stochastically determined assignment into good and bad faces, and computed cosine similarities between images in the different good/bad categories. These similarities were employed as interference terms in the quantum network model. In order to model interference between intermediate decisions and later confidence ratings, Kvam et al. (2015) employed a quantum sequential sampling model, involving a tridiagonal Hamiltonian, derived from the Feynman crystal model (Feynman & Hibbs, 1965). The diagonal elements represent a potential function to drive the amplitudes for confidence in the direction indicated by the dot motion, and the off diagonal entries diffuse amplitude to adjacent states. The quantum model predicted that, without an intermediate decision, amplitudes are pushed towards extreme confidence levels; but with an intermediate decision and subsequent processing of the stimuli (second stage processing), the flow of amplitude towards extreme confidence levels is less pronounced, as empirically observed.
Interference arises in the model because the second stage processing makes the initially commuting projectors for the intermediate decision and the subsequent confidence rating non-commuting.

In Kvam et al.'s (2014) prisoner's dilemma variant, a quantum model was built for how internal states of intention to cooperate or not relate to action. They assumed that the decision maker is initially in a superposition between being a cooperative versus a defective type of player, and the promise to cooperate induces a collapse to the cooperative type, which in turn increases the probability to cooperate with future opponents. Denolf et al. (2017) proposed a two-dimensional quantum model for the sequential version of the Prisoner's Dilemma game in Blanco et al. (2014). They assumed that the basis for belief judgments is related to the basis for action decisions by a unitary rotation. The main features in their model were an elaboration of assumptions (relative to previous quantum models for the Prisoner's Dilemma) regarding whether actions or beliefs could be considered compatible or incompatible.

Critical evaluation and controversy. White et al. (2014 aimed to show how the projection associated with the intermediate judgment could account for a change in second stimulus evaluation, as predicted by quantum theory. No specific fits were carried out, but the finding of the evaluation bias was considered to confirm the quantum prediction, based on certain assumptions (e.g., the relative placement of rays, which White et al., 2014, justified with consistency arguments). White et al. (2014) argued that the evaluation bias was an a priori prediction of quantum theory. They examined Hogarth and Einhorn's (1992) anchoring and adjustment model, as in that model an eventual judgment from multiple pieces of evidence can be influenced by intermediate judgments. However, White et al. (2014) concluded that reasonable parameterizations of Hogarth and Einhorn's (1992) model do not allow the evaluation bias. White et al. (2020) further compared the quantum model with Hogarth and Einhorn's (1992), extending the specification of both models. In their fits it was not possible to conclude in favor of one model. Memory or attention processes could also potentially account for the evaluation bias. For example, the intermediate judgment potentially creates a stronger memory trace for the first stimulus, which then creates a stronger contrast with the second stimulus. Arguably, such potential explanations for the evaluation bias are complementary to the formal description from formal theory. Yearsley and Pothos (2016) compared the quantum model to a matched classical probability model, which also incorporated error-prone decisions; the two models primarily differed in that the quantum model allows for measurement effects from constructive judgments, but in the classical model measurement was not assumed to influence the mental state (reporting a belief does not provide new evidence for a Bayesian update). Because the empirical findings showed an impact from the number of intermediate judgments, the proposed classical model performed poorly compared to the quantum model. Yearsley and Pothos's model accounted for the effects of intermediate judgments in a parameter-free way (the classical and quantum models were fit to a subset of data involving no intermediate judgements, and the fits to the rest of the data were essentially tests of generalization). However, there are a number of choices made in the construction of the models whose impact is unclear. In particular this was one of the first quantum cognition papers to utilize POVM measurements to fit behavioral data, and it is not known how much the success of the model depends on the details of the POVMs.

Wang and Busemeyer (2016b) compared their quantum model with a closely matched Markov model, but only the former could produce interference effects and so account for empirical results. Additional hidden states can be added to the Markov model to accommodate differences between categorization-decision and decision alone conditions (He & Jiang, 2018), but arguably such an approach becomes less principled. In addition to the Markov model, these authors also discussed a signal detection model (Ashby & Townsend, 1986), for which, following categorization, the eventual decision can still depend on the stimulus; for the Markov and quantum models, once a categorization is made, the decision depends only on the categorization. The authors argued that signal detection theory would have trouble accounting for interference, unless one introduces post hoc assumptions regarding how the response regions (for the categorizations and/or the decisions) change boundaries depending on stimulus categorization. Moreira and Wichert's (2017) quantum model for the categorization, decision violation of the law of total probability raises some questions. For example, it is unclear that the vectors in the quantum network are equivalent to the ones employed to compute the similarities. Additionally, Moreira and Wichert (2017) assumed a renormalization of the image vectors to occupy the negative part of the vector space, because this leads to a restriction to just destructive interference effects (as empirically observed), but this assumption could do with further justification. Kvam et al. (2015) compared the quantum model to a Markov random walk model (Pike, 1966), which uses an analogous tridiagonal intensity matrix; both models were matched in terms of number and purpose of parameters. Markov random walk and sequential sampling models generally (e.g., Ratcliff & Smith, 2004) assume a trajectory of values across time, so that a specific accumulation point exists for each hypothesis at each time point (i.e., all uncertainty is epistemic). Measurement simply records these existing values and there is no default mechanism for how a judgment affects performance. Quantum models assume a dispersive wave of beliefs at each moment until a choice is made that collapses the wave; that is, choices can change the mental state. The empirically observed interference effect between intermediate decision and subsequent confidence rating could only be predicted by the quantum model, not the Markov one, and a Bayesian model comparison favored the former. One can ask whether the advantage of the quantum model could arise from other model features (e.g., the initial state and evolution operator). This is possible, however, the prediction of no interference by the Markov model is a fairly general property (not dependent on model details). Markov models could produce interference by assuming that the intermediate decision causes a change in the evolution, but this avenue does not appear promising in this case; Kvam et al. (2015) examined and ruled out several possibilities of this type for their data. Kvam et al.'s (2014) quantum model predicted their prisoner's dilemma data better than a matched classical model, which lacked capacity for a constructive influence from the intermediate judgment. Denolf et al. (2017) allowed outcomes of a rating scale to be non-orthogonal vectors, which is uncommon in quantum measurement theory. However, their approach is broadly equivalent to an assumption of POVM measurement and has the advantage of requiring only a low dimensional space for representation.

div.head: Memory
div.p: By quantum memory we refer to the study of human memory through quantum probability theory. This term has different meaning in quantum computing, which is not our focus.

Empirical research. Bruza et al. (2009) followed up on an earlier idea by Nelson and McEvoy (2008), who had suggested that word associations might display behavior analogous to 'spooky action at a distance', that is, break the Bell inequality bound. Bruza et al. (2009) proposed a cued recall experiment involving cues that can have multiple senses, e.g., the cue bat can have an animal and a sports sense. The study part would be divided into parts, so that in each part a cue word would be presented with words which activate different senses (e.g., in one study part the cue bat might appear with the words ball and glove, so as to activate the sports context). Post-study, two cue words would be presented individually with a request to recall other words from the lists just studied, with a view to examine the word senses activated by the cues, by interpreting the recalled words. The authors outlined a 2x2 design of cues (two cues, each of which with two senses), which could potentially lead to violations of the Bell bound.

Brainerd, Reyna, and colleagues (Brainerd & Reyna, 2008;Brainerd et al., 2010) have explored memory overdistribution effects in recognition. Consider the case of participants asked to study a word list, as part of a memory experiment. Subsequently, in a test phase, participants are exposed to a test list with words in four categories: targets, distractors semantically related to the targets, and unrelated distractors. Recognition instructions are varied factorially with the test items. The test probes included questions such as "is it a Target" (T), "is it a related distractor" (R), "is it a target or a related distractor" (T or R), which correspond to probabilities ( ), ( ), ( ) respectively. The major finding is overdistribution, defined as ( ) + ( ) > ( ) (this is a disjunction error). Classically, since the categories of T and R are mutually exclusive, we expect instead that ( ) + ( ) = ( ). The surprising finding is that some test items are judged as both presented and not presented from test (Brainerd & Reyna, 2008;Brainerd et al., 2010). Together with overdistribution, we also have a subadditivity effect, which occurs when the probability of accepting an item in mutually exclusive and exhaustive categories is greater than one. So, subadditivity also indicates ( ) + ( ) + ( ) > ( âª âª ) = 1, where NR is a non-related distractor, and T, R, NR comprise the set of mutually exclusive and exhaustive cues, but in this case there is no overt cue.

The work of Atmanspacher and Filk (2010) raises the possibility of violations of classical constraints in relation to a sequence of events in memory. Consider a particular question, for example whether a hypothetical suspect is guilty or not, and evidence related to this question at different time points, t1, t2, t3. Assume that the suspect is initially considered innocent and all the pieces of evidence (fairly weakly) indicate guilt. Suppose next that participants are asked whether they changed their impression of whether the suspect is guilty or not across different time points, e.g., denote as S ( 5 , T ) the number of such 'change' judgments across the initial and final time points. Set theory can be used to show that S ( 5 , T ) â¤ S ( 5 , " ) + S ( " , T ), which is a statement that the number of changes across the extreme time points is bounded by the sum of changes at each pair of consecutive time points (Atmanspacher & Filk, 2010; this inequality is a version of the Temporal Bell inequality, which is considered in more detail in the Perception section). Interestingly, Waddup et at. (2023) showed this inequality to be violated, in a decision experiment, broadly as above. Bruza et al. (2009) proposed an entangled state quantum model to formally represent the idea that changes in one part of the system automatically imply changes in the other (this is the 'spooky action at a distance', though in a memory priming experiment there is no physical distance; Nelson & McEvoy, 2008). They proposed that words in memory are represented as superpositions, and cues are measurements formalized in terms of different basis vectors. Words were modeled as tensor products of components corresponding to different meanings. They proposed a distinction between separable versus non-separable meaning/ semantic spaces using the concept of entanglement. Brainerd et al. (2013) developed a quantum representation model for subadditivity in a particular three list variant of their recognition paradigm (Brainerd et al., 2012). Each item in the empirical test was represented in a five-dimensional Hilbert space, such that three dimensions corresponded to verbatim features (mostly superficial characteristics) for each of the three lists, one dimension to gist features (mostly semantic/ abstract characteristics, but also relational, contextual information), and one dimension to distractor features. The model in Brainerd et al. (2013) was termed the QEM model (quantum episodic memory model). Brainerd et al. (2015) provided an elaboration of the Brainerd et al. (2013) model and presented it as a formalization of fuzzy trace theory (Reyna, 2008;Reyna & Brainerd, 1995), which we call QEM+, abusing notation for simplicity. In the QEM+, each item is represented in a three-dimensional Hilbert space, with basis vectors corresponding to verbatim, gist, and other information (information not matching the cue's either surface or semantic content). According to QEM+, subadditivity is directly predicted because the retrieval probabilities are computed in a way that the contribution from the gist information occurs twice for verbatim questions. Denolf and Lambert-Mogiliansky (2016) noted that in the QEM/ QEM+ models verbatim information, gist information etc. are represented with orthogonal vectors, which makes them mutually exclusive (i.e., completely accepting gist information for a test cue means completely rejecting verbatim information). Instead, they assumed that verbatim and gist information is incompatible, so that a person can adopt one perspective or the other, but not both. Denolf and Lambert-Mogiliansky (2016) called this model the Complementary Memory Types (CMT) model. Denolf and Lambert-Mogiliansky model (2016) made a symmetry assumption for the representation of the gist information. In a four-dimensional space, three basis vectors corresponded to verbatim information for each one of the three memorized lists (in the experiment covered by the model) and one to unrelated information. An alternative basis set corresponded to gist information. Gist information was modeled with a single vector, with equal amplitudes along the basis vectors for each memorized list and zero for unrelated information.

div.head: Quantum cognitive models
div.p: An approach based on incompatibility was further developed by Trueblood and Hemmer (2017; see also Broekaert & Busemeyer, 2017). In their Generalized Quantum Episodic Memory Model (GQEM), verbatim, gist, and new information are assumed incompatible. Each of the three types of information corresponds to a two-dimensional basis, obviating the assumption of differing dimensionalities in Denolf and Lambert-Mogiliansky (2016). Acceptance probabilities under verbatim and gist instructions are computed by first evaluating acceptance based on gist information and, if this produces a negative outcome, evaluating acceptance on verbatim information (gist information has been argued to be processed more rapidly; Brainerd et al., 1999). An analogous assumption was employed with paradigms in which training items are presented in different contexts.

Recently, Manning (2021) proposed a preliminary quantum wavefunction framework for retrieval of information from memory. Manning compared how people retrieve information and suggested that the form of autocorrelation patterns exhibit some quantum characteristics. Manning outlined a preliminary memory model based on a weighted combination of prior experiences, but not proposed a full mathematical model. Waddup et al. (2023) demonstrated that memory representations can show violations of the temporal Bell inequality. In physics, such results can be interpreted as evidence for quantum structure, as long as certain preconditions are met (notably non-signaling in time, that is, that there is no signaling across time points).

Critical evaluation and controversy. Bruza et al. (2009) proposed several experiments to test their entanglement model. But a concrete empirical examination has yet to be performed. If an empirical test is successful, it would provide evidence that words are contextual in the sense of violating the Bell inequality (see the later work by , discussed in the section on "Conceptual combinations"). Note, tests of Bell's inequality in physics require rigorous demonstrations of non-signaling, which is hard for behavioral experiments (this is the one contribution from Cervantes & Dzhafarov, 2018).

The overdistribution and subadditivity effects in memory recognition have challenged standard recognition models, such as the one-process signal detection model (Glanzer & Adams, 1990), and standard source recognition models, such as the source monitoring model (Batchelder & Riefer 1990), which unelaborated, cannot predict these effects. By contrast, Brainerd et al. (2013) reported superior fits for the QEM for the Brainerd et al. (2012) data, when compared to their own predominant model for the episodic subadditivity effect (the overdistribution model). Brainerd et al. (2015) reported results supporting predictions from their QEM+, notably that it is specifically subadditivity and not superadditivity that is predicted and also that empirical manipulations which enhance reliance on gist information and/ or decrease influence from verbatim information should both increase subadditivity. Both QEM and QEM+ are elegant in their parsimony, but make limited use of quantum features, questioning the necessity of quantum theory. For example, Brainerd et al. (2015) noted that a key assumption in fuzzy trace theory is that gist information allows the same item to be perceived as belonging to different categories, which is why in the QEM+ gist information appears twice in some retrieval probabilities, producing subadditivity. Denolf and Lambert-Mogiliansky (2016) and Trueblood and Hemmer's (2017) proposals that fuzzy trace theory can be elaborated with an assumption of incompatibility between verbatim and gist information make more use of uniquely quantum features. Denolf and Lambert-Mogiliansky (2016) reported coverage of both subadditivity and favorable comparisons with QEM+. Trueblood and Hemmer (2017) noted some problematic predictions from the QEM+. For example, retrieval probabilities are predicted to be equal under verbatim and verbatim plus gist instructions, but empirical results show the latter to be higher. Moreover, the QEM+ predicts a higher probability of accepting a test cue with verbatim instructions, compared to gist instructions, again contrary to empirical data. Regarding the overdistribution model, they noted that the model can cover the episodic overdistribution effect, but not the subadditivity effect (the model is underspecified regarding acceptance probabilities under unrelated new instructions). They conducted a hierarchical Bayesian model comparison between their GQEM model and the overdistribution model, based on a new experiment using the item memory variant of the memory task (test cues can be old or new) and results from Kellen et al. (2014) using the source memory variant (training cues presented in different contexts). The former comparison favored the GQEM. The latter comparison favored the overdistribution model, but GQEM was shown to produce equivalent fits to the data.

Manning's (2021) and Waddup et al. (2023) offer support for quantum-like structures in memory, but their work falls short of a memory model based on quantum theory, which is able to directly describe some existing data and offer predictions. Moreover, a proposal of quantum-like representations in memory currently lacks motivation, e.g., in terms of efficiency or adaptive considerations (this problem is recognized, but not resolved, in Waddup et al., 2023).

div.head: Perception
div.p: Empirical research. This section reviews two studies related to bistable perception. Bistable perception refers to the unstable perception that occurs with ambiguous figures, such as the Necker cube, which can be perceived in one of two ways, each revealing a different interpretation of the figure. Typically, there is a sensation of effort in switching between interpretations. Atmanspacher et al. (2004) analyzed past results measuring the frequency of reversals in a Necker cube bistable perception task, where the Necker cube is presented non-continuously over time. They examined past work demonstrating an experimental effect between the off-time of the noncontinuous presentation and the switching period T and found that the switching period shows a quadratic relationship with the off-time interval. The effect matches the prediction from the quantum Zeno effect in physics. Conte et al. (2009) employed a paradigm involving the sequential presentation of two ambiguous figures (each figure could be perceived in two different ways) or the presentation of just one of the figures. It is possible that seeing a first figure may result in some bias in perceiving the second figure and indeed Conte et al. (2009) reported a violation of the law of total probability in the sense that ( U â§ S ) + ( U â§ U ) â ( U ) (A and B refer to the two figures and the + and -signs to the two possible ways of perceiving them).

Quantum cognitive models. Conte et al. (2009) argued that the violation of the law of total probability in their bistable perception results indicates that the mental states corresponding to the interpretation of each figure are superpositions, so that interference effects can arise (see Equation 2). They presented a simple quantum model (using the same number of parameters as data points), which reproduced the results. Atmanspacher et al. (2004) and Atmanspacher and Filk (2010) developed a quantum oscillator model (which they call the Necker Zeno model) for bistable perception. The model works on a bipartite system, whose dynamics without any observation are governed by a particular unitary. Observations of the systems are modeled by projections onto the two eigenstates, corresponding to each of the two interpretations of the Necker cube. The main prediction of the model is the quantum Zeno effect, which relates three characteristic times: the switching time T, the oscillation characteristic time without observation, and the time between each observation. The model can be applied to non-continuous presentation bistable perception tasks. In general, the model predicts a quadratic relationship between the reversal time and the off-time. As discussed, the model broadly matches empirical evidence (recall, Yearsley & Pothos, 2016, offered a direct demonstration of the quantum Zeno effect in decision making).

Additionally, Atmanspacher and Filk (2010) showed that their Necker Zeno model predicts violations of the temporal Bell inequality. The temporal Bell inequality is a "temporal" version of the standard Bell inequality: it is expressed in terms of correlations between question outcomes for the same system between three (or four) time points (Yearsley & Pothos, 2014). Atmanspacher and Filk's (2010) model illustrates an example where the violation of this temporal Bell inequality is maximal. Atmanspacher and Filk (2010) also outlined the kind of empirical tests which could be employed to demonstrate a violation of a temporal Bell inequality, based on manipulations which ostensibly lead to interpretation switches with time (recall, Waddup et al., 2023, offered such a demonstration, in memory).

Critical evaluation and controversy. One concern about the Conte et al. (2009) results is the small sample size used in their study. Another concern is the strict interpretation that the perceptual results arise from a quantum process; there was limited consideration of possible classical explanations for the results. Atmanspacher and Filk (2010) reported that their quantum model accurately predicted the quadratic relation between lifetimes T and 'time off' found in previous research. Their work also makes a further bold implication: in order to violate the temporal Bell inequality, it has to be the case that participants would tend to not switch interpretation across 5 , " and also not switch between " , T , but then switch across 5 , T , which violates an obvious intuition of transitivity. One plausible explanation for such a pattern of results would be that the relevant mental state is extended time-wise, that is, it does not have a well-defined trajectory through time. A timewise non-local mental state may extend, for example, across both periods 5 , " , so that one can no longer assume that an event at 5 caused changes at " . So, if the predictions from this work were to be empirically confirmed, there would be intriguing implications for understanding causality across time (Yearsley & Pothos, 2014).

Precise predictions from Atmanspacher and Filk's (2010) framework for when the temporal Bell inequality is likely to be violated depend on the details of how the Hamiltonian and observation operators are specified. Further work is needed to motivate (ideally pre-fit with pilot data) the various components of the quantum model.

Another issue is how tightly we can make an association between a putative violation of temporal Bell and quantum-like representations. In the Memory section, we considered Waddup et al.'s (2023) work; they employed a 'change' judgment which allowed testing of Bell's inequality, in a way which should eliminate signaling across time. In the Conceptual Combination section, we reviewed the controversy regarding signaling corrections (notably Cervantes & Dzhafarov, 2017). In both the present case and these other cases, a subtle point is the role of signaling checks in inferring quantum-like structure, an issue which has led to interpretative challenges.

div.head: Group-level Cognition
div.p: In this section we consider cognition at the group-level. This includes the study of information propagation and serial reproductions. Khrennikov (2020) explored the bandwagon effect, which is the tendency of people to adopt certain beliefs simply because of what others around them believe. The bandwagon effect is an example in social information propagation. Mutlu and Garibay (2021) studied the effects of propagation of competing information (e.g., good news vs bad news), as well as typical uncertainties in social media communications from unreliable agents. Waddup et al. (2021) explored the extent to which two interacting agents can flexibly adapt their actions, depending on the actions of each other. Waddup et al. (2021) employed a variant of a prisoner's dilemma paradigm, but with no Nash equilibrium and, instead, an arrangement for each agent such that particular combinations could reveal sensitivity to the counterpart's action. As expected, such sensitivity was empirically demonstrated, when testing the paradigm with participants interacting with a hypothetical (experiment controlled) counterpart. Moreover, they checked for signaling and, in some cases, sensitivity to the counterpart's decisions was unaccompanied by signaling. Huang et al. (2022) and Huang et al. (2024c) described a large-scale empirical study about emotion transmission in serial reproduction. The main finding was that emotion transmission exhibited a nonlinear effect that has been argued to be beyond the scope of a Bayesian autoregressive model.

div.head: Quantum Cognitive models
div.p: Cabello et al. (2012) presented a quantum social network that builds on the same graph theoretical structure as that of a classical network, whereby vertices describe agents and edges indicate agent interactions. In classical social networks, edges reflect preexisting properties of the agents. By contrast, in quantum social networks, edges are represented with quantum states, so that without some measuring operation it is not possible to characterize them in terms of specific properties. Cabello et al. 2012showed that for certain variations of the Lovasz sandwich theorem, there is no general social network that can outperform the quantum social network.

Khrennikov (2020) employed a quantum-like social 'lasing' model for information propagation in social networks, which he argued explains the bandwagon effect. In this model, each agent in the social network carries some social energy, and information transmission in the social network is analogous to stimulated emission of photons in quantum physics, except that in social communication, social action or social information, instead of photon signals is amplified. The bandwagon effect emerges naturally, as a result of Bose-Einstein statistics for indistinguishable photons in stimulated emissions.

Zhang and Busemeyer (2021) proposed a quantum walk model for idea propagation, between agents in a social network. The core of the model is a controlled unitary operator, which is defined as the tensor product between a matrix containing all controller bits and a unitary operator that turns on only when the controller bit is 1. This 'lifted' quantum walk model alleviates one important drawback of the previous, predominant approach, based on a non-lifted Hamiltonian, which could only accommodate symmetrical information flow (by contrast, information flow in a social network in Zhang & Busemeyer can also be asymmetrical).

Regarding the interaction of agents, Waddup et al. (2021) showed that the sensitivity of one agent to the actions of another precluded the description of decision probabilities with a four-way classical probability distribution (note, there were two actions for each of two agents) and violated the Bell inequality. They reported a simple quantum model which could accommodate the data, outperforming a simple model based on baseline Bayesian probabilities. Huang et al. (2022) offered a model for serial reproduction in group-level idea propagation. Assuming that serial reproduction is asymmetrical, Huang et al. (2022) adopted an idea similar to that of Zhang and Busemeyer (2021), to model serial reproduction through a quantum walk model. The quantum walk model could predict both nonlinear dynamics and order effects in serial reproduction.

div.head: Critical Evaluation and Controversies
div.p: Prior to Huang et al. (2022), previous work relating to quantum social networks has been at a theoretical level (e.g., in terms of information-theoretic application), but with less emphasis on corresponding psychological implications. As a result, prior examinations of such ideas have not involved application to behavioral data. Huang et al. (2022) applied the lifted quantum walk model to the largest serial reproduction dataset, at the time of their investigation. However, Huang et al.'s (2022) model incorporates an assumption of the easiest/ simplest information path in a social network and so more work is needed to examine alternative approaches, as well as the general usefulness of their quantum model in understanding social communications.

Another potential problem of existing quantum models of social networks is that the necessity of or even advantage for a quantum approach has not been sufficiently demonstrated. For example, the bandwagon effect, as explained in Khrennikov (2020), could also be explained by classical models. Even if a quantum model explains some data well, there is an onus on proponents of such formalisms to show that quantum features are particularly well-suited to the empirical phenomenon of interest. Huang et al. (2022) did point out that their lifted quantum walk model could potentially explain order effects, which is a qualitative effect not easily explained by a classical Markov model. However, clearly, more work is needed along similar lines.
